{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2015}} {{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians --> | name = John Grant | background = solo_singer | image = John Grant 2014.jpg | image_size = | landscape = no | caption = Grant performing at [[Jena]], [[Kulturarena]] on July 24, 2014. | birth_name = John William Grant | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1968|7|25}} | birth_place = [[Buchanan, Michigan]], U.S. | origin = [[Parker, Colorado]], U.S. | genre = [[Folk music|Folk]], [[alternative rock]], [[indie rock]], [[electronic rock]], [[synthpop]], [[New wave music|new wave]], [[soft rock]] | occupation = | instrument = Vocals, piano, [[synthesizer]] | years_active = | label = [[Bella Union]], [[Partisan Records|Partisan]], [[Sena (record company)|Sena]] | associated_acts = [[The Czars]], [[Midlake]] | website = {{URL|johngrantmusic.com}} }}
'''John Grant''' (born July 25, 1968) is an American singer-songwriter and former member of the Denver-based alternative rock band [[The Czars]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.musicomh.com/reviews/albums/john-grant-with-midlake-queen-of-denmark|title=John Grant – Queen Of Denmark {{!}} Album Reviews {{!}} musicOMH|website=Musicomh.com|access-date=2018-02-24}}</ref> After recording six studio albums with the Czars, he embarked on a solo career in 2010.
His debut solo album ''[[Queen of Denmark]]'' was named in 2010 the best album of the year by ''[[Mojo (magazine)|Mojo]]''.<ref name=numberone /> In 2015, his third studio album, ''[[Grey Tickles, Black Pressure]]'' received widespread critical acclaim,<ref name=charts>[http://www.metacritic.com/music/grey-tickles-black-pressure/john-grant/critic-reviews Grey Tickles, Black Pressure - Metacritic]. Metacritic. Retrieved 7 October 2015.</ref> and peaked at number 5 in the [[UK albums chart]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.officialcharts.com/artist/6221/john-grant/|title=John Grant Uk Charts album|publisher=Officialcharts|accessdate=18 November 2018}}</ref> His fourth album ''Love is Magic'' was released in 2018 and entered into the top 20 in the UK.<ref name=charts />
== Early life == Grant was born in Buchanan, Michigan but later raised in Parker, [[Colorado]] by his engineer father and housewife mother.<ref name="Grundy">{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2010/jun/20/john-grant-queen-of-denmark|title=John Grant: 'It was horrifying. I got out just in time' {{!}} Interview|last=Grundy|first=Gareth|date=2010-06-19|website=the Guardian|access-date=2018-02-24}}</ref> He was brought up in an orthodox Methodist household, at odds with his emerging sexuality. At high school he was, on occasion, bullied both physically and emotionally by his fellow pupils.<ref name="bbc.co.uk">{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b0848bll|title=Reykjavik, Series 3, Reimagining the City - BBC Radio 4|website=BBC|access-date=2018-02-24}}</ref> Grant now sings openly, often with caustic candour, about the landmark experiences that have pained and shaped his complex life to date; It took Grant until his mid-twenties to feel comfortable with his sexuality, having been raised in an environment where it was "clear that those people were going to hell".<ref name="Grundy"/> Grant moved to Germany in 1988 to continue his study of languages and is fluent in German, Russian and Spanish, as well as Icelandic, the language of his newly adopted home.<ref name="bbc.co.uk"/>
==The Czars== {{main article|The Czars}} After some years in Germany studying and working Grant returned to the US in 1994. Along with Chris Pearson, Andy Moneley, Jeff Linsenmaier and Roger Green he formed the alternative, [[Denver]]-based rock band [[The Czars]]. They enjoyed critical success, releasing six studio albums, but commercial recognition proved elusive. These were troubling years for Grant as he battled with drug and alcohol addictions. On top of this he struggled with severe anxiety, a condition that has stalked him throughout his adult life.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/mar/03/john-grant-interview-singer-songwriter|title=John Grant: 'I wanted to let some of the anger out'|last=Lynskey|first=Dorian|date=2013-03-03|website=the Guardian|access-date=2018-02-26}}</ref> While still with The Czars, Grant, who had always been a huge fan of [[Cocteau Twins]], met with [[Simon Raymonde]]. Raymonde had recently started the record label [[Bella Union]] and although not particularly looking for new acts at that time he sensed the potential. He agreed to produce two Czars albums. Unfortunately the alcohol and substance abuse continued for Grant and after releasing ''Sorry I Made You Cry'' in 2004 the band split.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2010/jun/20/john-grant-queen-of-denmark|title=John Grant: 'It was horrifying. I got out just in time' {{!}} Interview|last=Grundy|first=Gareth|date=2010-06-19|website=the Guardian|access-date=2018-02-26}}</ref> Following the demise of the band, Grant moved to New York and "returned to mainstream society", as he put it at the time.<ref name="Grundy"/> He worked for a while as a waiter before taking up work as a medical interpreter for Russian in a city hospital. He felt compelled to continue writing music during this time. It was also during this time that Grant began the process of confronting the addictions that had been so destructive during his time with the Czars.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/music/what-to-listen-to/john-grant-interview-miss-drugs-time/|title=John Grant interview: 'I miss drugs all the time'|last=Smith|first=Patrick|date=2017-04-26|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2018-02-24|issn=0307-1235}}</ref> ''[[Best Of (The Czars album)|Best Of]]'' was released in December 2014 on the [[Bella Union]] label.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.musicomh.com/reviews/albums/czars-best|title=The Czars – Best Of {{!}} Album Reviews |website=Musicomh.com|access-date=2018-02-26}}</ref>
== Solo career == === ''Queen of Denmark'' (2010-2012) === While still working and writing in New York, it was the Texan folk rock group [[Midlake]] who eventually persuaded Grant to return to the recording studio.<ref name="The Independent">{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/john-grant-this-addictive-personality-permeates-my-entire-being-8547573.html|title=John Grant: 'This addictive personality permeates my entire being'|date=2013-03-24|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-02-25}}</ref> They joined him to record and produce what would be his first solo album; ''[[Queen of Denmark (album)|Queen of Denmark]]''. It was released on the [[Bella Union]] label in April 2010. Described as a "deeply personal album" it explores Grant's struggles with alcohol and drug addiction as well as his personal struggle to reconcile his sexuality. "Brothers" was how Grant described Midlake when interviewed at a later date for the publication MusicOhm.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.musicomh.com/features/interviews/john-grant|title=Interview: John Grant {{!}} Interviews |website=Musicomh.com|access-date=2018-02-25}}</ref>
''[[Queen of Denmark (album)|Queen of Denmark]]'' received critical acclaim and was chosen as Best Album Of 2010 by the British music magazine [[Mojo (magazine)|Mojo]].<ref name=numberone>{{Cite news|url=https://www.albumoftheyear.org/list/43-mojos-top-50-albums-of-2010/|title=MOJO's Top 50 Albums of 2010|work=Album of The Year|access-date=2018-02-25}}</ref> Grant was also nominated as Best Breakthrough Act at the Mojo Awards and won Best Live Act for Mojo.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.brooklynvegan.com/mojos-top-album/|title=MOJO’s Top Albums of 2010 + John Grant tour dates & stream|website=BrooklynVegan|access-date=2018-02-25}}</ref> Filmmaker [[Andrew Haigh]] used several songs from his album ''Queen of Denmark'' are used in Haigh's 2011 movie ''[[Weekend (2011 film)|Weekend]]''.<ref name=out>[http://www.out.com/entertainment/music/2013/01/30/listen-john-grant-pale-green-ghosts LISTEN: John Grant's 'Pale Green Ghosts']. ''[[Out (magazine)|Out]]'', January 30, 2013.</ref>
In 2012 at London's Meltdown Festival while performing on stage with [[Hercules and Love Affair|Hercules & Love Affair]], Grant announced that he was HIV positive.<ref name="The Independent"/>
===''Pale Green Ghosts'' (2013-2014)=== During a trip to Iceland to perform at the [[Airwaves Festival]], Grant met Birgir Þórarinsson aka Biggi Veira of Icelandic electronic pop group [[GusGus]]. The electronic, synthesized dance sounds that Grant was looking for and experimented with in Veira's studio formed much of the backdrop to his second album ''[[Pale Green Ghosts]]'', which Veira himself produced. [[Sinéad O'Connor]] was guest vocalist on three of the tracks, including "It Doesn't Matter To Him". Grant was quickly and deeply touched by the people and landscape of Iceland, so much so that he now has a permanent home in [[Reykjavík]].
''Pale Green Ghosts'' was released in March 2013 to critical acclaim. ''Pale Green Ghosts'' was [[Rough Trade Records]] Album Of The Year,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/nov/20/rough-trade-poll-2013-john-grant-pale-green-ghosts|title=John Grant's Pale Green Ghosts tops Rough Trade shops poll of the best albums of 2013|date=2013-11-20|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=2018-02-26}}</ref> and number 2 in ''[[The Guardian]]'s'' Best Album of 2013.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2013/dec/19/best-albums-2013-john-grant-pale-green-ghosts-number-2|title=John Grant's Pale Green Ghosts tops Rough Trade shops poll of the best albums of 2013|date=2013-11-20|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=2018-02-26}}</ref> A nomination for Best Solo Artist at the [[Q Awards]] followed (with [[David Bowie]] and [[Laura Marling]] among the other nominees).<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/rockandpopmusic/10288729/David-Bowie-nominated-for-Q-Awards-2013.html|title=David Bowie nominated for Q Awards 2013|last=Vincent|first=Alice|date=2013-09-05|access-date=2018-02-26|issn=0307-1235}}</ref> A nomination for Best International Male Solo Artist at the [[Brit Awards]] in 2014 followed,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/brit-awards/10560925/Brit-Awards-nominations-2014-full-list.html|title=Brit Awards nominations 2014: full list|last=Reporters|first=Telegraph|date=2014-02-18|access-date=2018-02-26|issn=0307-1235}}</ref> and [[Attitude (magazine)|''Attitude'']] named Grant Man of The Year 2014.
In 2013 Grant put his linguistic skills to effect by translating [[Ásgeir Trausti]]'s album ''[[Dýrð í dauðaþögn]]''. The English version titled ''In the Silence'' was released in October of that year. In 2014 he co-wrote "No Prejudice", the Icelandic entry for the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2014|Eurovision Song Contest]] performed by [[Pollapönk]].
In 2014 Grant guested on the 40th anniversary release of [[Elton John]]'s ''[[Goodbye Yellow Brick Road]]'', covering the song "Sweet Painted Lady". Always on the lookout for likely or unlikely collaborations, Grant has been keen to explore his passion for electronic and dance music, guesting on the album ''[[The Feast of The Broken Heart]]'', by [[Hercules and Love Affair|Hercules & Love Affair]] and released on [[Moshi Moshi Records]].
In the first half of 2014, Grant joined British group [[Elbow (band)|Elbow]] on the North American leg of their tour. In October 2014, accompanied by the [[BBC Philharmonic Orchestra]], Grant recorded tracks from his first two albums for a concert on [[BBC Radio 6 Music]] arranged by [[Fiona Brice]]. This was released as an album: ''John Grant And The BBC Philharmonic Orchestra: Live In Concert''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.clashmusic.com/reviews/john-grant-live-in-concert-with-the-bbc-philharmonic-orchestra|title=John Grant - Live In Concert (With The BBC Philharmonic Orchestra)|work=[[Clash Magazine]]|access-date=2018-02-26}}</ref> Grant concluded 2014 with rave reviews following his UK concert hall tour with the [[Royal Northern Sinfonia]]. [[Clash (magazine)|ClashMusic.com]] wrote that the concert "could honestly be one of the greatest gigs of all time at London's [[Royal Festival Hall]]".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.clashmusic.com/live/live-report-john-grant-with-the-royal-northern-sinfonia-at-royal-festival-hall-london|title=Live Report: John Grant with The Royal Northern Sinfonia, at Royal Festival Hall, London|work=Clash Magazine|access-date=2018-02-26}}</ref> That night, he duetted with [[Alison Goldfrapp]] on (the [[Nancy Sinatra]] and [[Lee Hazlewood]] song) "[[Some Velvet Morning]]" at the Royal Albert Hall.
=== ''Grey Tickles, Black Pressure'' (2015-2017)=== 2015 saw Grant release his third solo album ''[[Grey Tickles, Black Pressure]]''. Recorded in [[Dallas]] and produced by [[John Congleton]], it featured guest vocalists [[Tracey Thorn]] ([[Everything But The Girl]]) and [[Amanda Palmer]] ([[The Dresden Dolls]]), and former [[Siouxsie and the Banshees]] drummer [[Budgie (musician)|Budgie]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/john-grant-mn0000218781/biography |title=John Grant Biography|website=AllMusic|access-date=2018-02-26}}</ref> Upon its release, the album was hailed by the likes of ''[[NME]]'',<ref>{{cite web |author= |url=http://www.nme.com/reviews/john-grant/16276 |title=NME Reviews – John Grant – 'Grey Tickles, Black Pressure' |publisher=Nme.Com |date= |accessdate=2015-10-19}}</ref> ''[[The Guardian]]''<ref>{{cite web |author=Alexis Petridis |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/oct/01/john-grant-grey-tickles-black-pressure-review |title=John Grant: Grey Tickles, Black Pressure review – trauma, jokes and joy | Music |publisher=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=2015-10-19}}</ref> and ''[[Mojo (magazine)|Mojo]]''.<ref>{{cite web |last=Trynka |first=Paul |url=http://www.mojo4music.com/21897/john-grant-grey-tickles-black-pressure/ |title=John Grant – Grey Tickles, Black Pressure | MOJO |publisher=Mojo4music.com |date=2015-10-02 |accessdate=2015-10-19}}</ref> Before embarking on a worldwide tour, Grant appeared on UK TV show ''[[Later with Jools Holland]]'' in early October. Accompanied on stage by a band including several backing singers and special guest drummer Budgie, Grant delivered a show at the Hammersmith Apollo in London, receiving a five-star review in the national press.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/nov/13/john-grant-live-review-apollo-hammersmith |author=Clarke, Betty |title=John Grant review – leaves his audience awestruck and on his feet |publisher=The Guardian |date=November 13, 2015}}</ref> In July 2015, Grant played [[Glastonbury Festival|Glastonbury]] and [[Latitude Festival|Latitude]] festivals before embarking on a world tour. The following year, he toured across much of the US and Europe. In October of that year he made a third appearance on the [[BBC Two]] show [[Later... With Jools Holland]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p00b7n6r|title=John Grant - I Wanna Go To Marz, Later... with Jools Holland, Series 37, Later... with Jools Holland - BBC Two|website=BBC|access-date=2018-02-26}}</ref>
Grant co-wrote and recorded the track "I Don't Want To Hurt You" with [[Robbie Williams]] which features in Williams' album ''[[The Heavy Entertainment Show]]'', released November 2016.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nme.com/news/music/robbie-williams-strips-naked-new-magazine-cover-1825210|title=Robbie Williams strips naked for new magazine cover - NME|date=2016-11-05|work=NME|access-date=2018-02-26}}</ref>
In 2016, Grant performed a solo show at the [[Royal Albert Hall]], which was met with rave reviews. He was joined on stage by [[Richard Hawley]] who performed "Disappointing" from ''Grey Tickles, Black Pressure''. Also guesting were [[Cate Le Bon]], who duetted on "Torn Between Two Lovers" – a song made famous by [[Mary MacGregor]] – and [[Kylie Minogue]] in a performance of "Glacier". Kylie invited Grant back to the Royal Albert Hall to duet with her on "Confide In Me" for [[A Kylie Christmas (concert series)|A Kylie Christmas]] in December that year.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/music/what-to-listen-to/kylie-christmas-royal-albert-hall-review/|title=Kylie Minogue brings early festive cheer to the Royal Albert Hall – review|last=McCormick|first=Neil|date=2016-12-10|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2018-02-26|issn=0307-1235}}</ref> Two songs from 2013 "Black Belt" and "Pale Green Ghosts" appeared on Haigh's HBO series ''[[Looking (TV series)|Looking]]''. On December 3, Grant was the subject of [[BBC Radio 4]]'s Reimagining the City, where he took listeners around Reykjavik.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Reimagining the City: Reykjavik, December 3, 2016 |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b0848bll |website=bbc.co.uk |accessdate=2016-12-03}}</ref>
In 2017, Grant appeared at the Hay Literary Festival in conversation with [[Cosey Fanni Tutti]] ([[Throbbing Gristle]]/[[Chris & Cosey]]), to discuss her autobiography ''Art Sex Music'', which was a ''[[The Sunday Times|Sunday Times]]'', ''[[The Daily Telegraph|Telegraph]]'' and [[Rough Trade Records]] Book of the Year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.hayfestival.com/p-12424-cosey-fanni-tutti-and-john-grant.aspx|title=Cosey Fanni Tutti and John Grant - Hay Festival|website=Hay Festival|access-date=2018-02-26}}</ref> Grant announced in 2017 that he had signed with publishers [[Little, Brown and Company]] to write his autobiography.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thebookseller.com/news/little-brown-buys-musician-john-grants-autobiography-507386|title=Little, Brown buys musician John Grant's autobiography {{!}} The Bookseller |website=Thebookseller.com |access-date=2018-02-26}}</ref> 2017 also saw Grant curate North Atlantic Flux: Sounds From Smoky Bay, a four-day event celebrating the best in Nordic and Scandinavian culture as part of Hull's year as UK City Of Culture. The festival, a collaboration with Curated Place, went on to win three awards at The Drum UK Event Awards, including the prestigious Cultural Event Of The Year. Highlights of the festival included performances from [[Susanne Sundfør]], [[GusGus]], Tonik Ensemble, Nils Bech, [[Adelle Stripe]], Wrangler and Grant himself, who also gave a two-hour Q&A hosted by writer and poet [[Adelle Stripe]] and later described as "enthralling".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2017/may/01/john-grant-north-atlantic-flux-festival-review-hull-city-culture|title=John Grant's North Atlantic Flux review – rollercoaster ride through bold music|last=Simpson|first=Dave|date=2017-05-01|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=2018-02-26}}</ref> In July, Grant returned to the Royal Albert Hall to contribute to a fund-raising event on behalf of [[Stonewall (charity)|Stonewall]], for a conversation with [[Elizabeth Fraser]] of the [[Cocteau Twins]]: the evening marked the 50th anniversary of the Sexual Offenses Act 1967.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.royalalberthall.com/tickets/events/2017/john-grant-and-elizabeth-fraser-in-conversation/|title=John Grant and Elizabeth Fraser in conversation — Royal Albert Hall|website=Royal Albert Hall|access-date=2018-02-26}}</ref> That month, Grant also joined a distinguished line up celebrating the music of [[Scott Walker (singer)|Scott Walker]], as part of the BBC's Late Night Proms. [[Jules Buckley]]'s Heritage Orchestra joined special guests Grant, [[Susanne Sundfør]], [[Richard Hawley]] and [[Jarvis Cocker]] to perform a string of Walker's songs. The event was broadcast on [[BBC Four]], [[BBC Radio 3]] and [[BBC Radio 6 Music]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/events/ex9whn|title=Prom 15: The Songs of Scott Walker (1967–70)|website=BBC Music Events|access-date=2018-02-26}}</ref> Grant also recorded "Mountaineers", a duet with [[Susanne Sundfør]] for her album ''[[Music for People in Trouble]]'', which was released in August 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.clashmusic.com/news/susanne-sundf%C3%B8r-x-john-grant-combine-on-mountaineers|title=Susanne Sundfør x John Grant Combine On 'Mountaineers'|work=Clash Magazine|access-date=2018-02-26}}</ref>
Having toured with [[Elbow (band)|Elbow]] in the US in 2014, Grant teamed up with [[Guy Garvey]] to record a duet version of Elbow's "Kindling (Fickle Flame)", which was released in September 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.clashmusic.com/live/elbow-announce-new-john-grant-collaboration|title=elbow Announce New John Grant Collaboration|work=Clash|access-date=2018-02-26}}</ref> Grant was a guest vocalist on ''The Great Distraction'', an album by Leeds-based art–electro rock quintet [[Vessels (band)|Vessels]]. The single "Erase the Tapes" featuring Grant was released in September 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://diymag.com/2017/09/22/vessels-john-grant-erase-the-tapes-listen|title=Vessels team up with John Grant on 'Erase The Tapes'|website=DIY|access-date=2018-02-26}}</ref>
As well as recording his fourth solo album, due for release in Autumn 2018, Grant has been working on a side project – Creep Show; a collaboration with Wrangler's [[Stephen Mallinder]], Phil Winter and Benge.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.clashmusic.com/news/john-grant-confirms-new-creep-show-project|title=John Grant Confirms New Creep Show Project|work=Clash Magazine|access-date=2018-02-26}}</ref> Described as experimental pop and surreal funk, the first single "Modern Parenting" from the album ''Mr Dynamite'' was released on January 30, the full album was released on March 16th 2018.
=== ''Love Is Magic'' (2018-present)=== On July 9, 2018, Grant released a short teaser video on social media. The following day, together with the announcement of his fourth album, ''Love Is Magic'', a song of the same name, taken from the new album, was released as a digital download and lyric video. The album ''Love Is Magic'' was released in October with favorable reviews.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.metacritic.com/music/love-is-magic/john-grant/critic-reviews |title=''Love is Magic'' Critic rRviews on Metacritic|publisher=Metacritic|accessdate=2 November 2018}}</ref> In a 5 out of 5 star review, ''[[The Independent]]'' described the record as "sardonic wit and heart-stopping drops of sheer honesty",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/reviews/john-grant-love-is-magic-review-album-release-date-tracklist-tour-dates-a8578481.html |title=''Love is Magic'' review|publisher=The Independent|date=11 October 2018|first=Helen |last=Brown|accessdate=2 November 2018|archiveurl=http://archive.is/Nt16R|archivedate=18 November 2018}}</ref> and ''NME'' hailed it as an album of "arch brilliance that also makes room for quiet introspection".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/reviews/album/john-grant-love-magic-album-review |title=''Love is Magic'' review|publisher=NME|date=9 October 2018|first=El |last=Hunt|accessdate=2 November 2018}}</ref> Grant then went on tour in the UK with a full band including Budgie on drums,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.musicomh.com/reviews/live/john-grant-brixton-academy-london|first=Helen|last=Clarke|title=John Grant @ Brixton Academy, London|work=Musicomh|date=30 October 2018|accessdate=1 November 2018}}</ref> before embarking on a world tour from November.

{{Infobox person | name = John Hasted | image = |birth_date = February 17, 1921 |death_date = May 4, 2002 | occupation = [[Physicist]], [[Parapsychology|Parapsychologist]], writer}}
'''John Barrett Hasted''' (February 17, 1921 – May 4, 2002) was a [[British people|British]] physicist and [[folk music]]ian.<ref>David Gregory. (2002). ''In Memoriam: John Hasted, 1921-2002''. Canadian Folk Music/Bulletin de musique folklorique canadienne, Vol 36, No. 2. pp. 3-8.</ref>
==Biography== Hasted was born in Woodbridge, Suffolk. He attended [[Winchester College]] and won a choral scholarship to [[New College, Oxford]], where he read chemistry and later focused on atomic physics.<ref name=Hunt/>
From 1968 until his retirement he was head of experimental physics at Birkbeck College, London. He was the author of ''Physics Of Atomic Collisions'' (1964), ''Aqueous Dielectrics'' (1973), ''The Metal Benders'' (1981), and his autobiography, ''Alternative Memoirs'' (1992).
He was also active as a folk singer, folk club organiser, and leading light of the Second British [[Folk Revival]].<ref name=Hunt>Ken Hunt. [https://www.theguardian.com/news/2002/sep/09/guardianobituaries.obituaries "John Hasted"]. ''The Guardian''. September 9, 2002.</ref>
==Parapsychology==
Hasted was a believer in [[psychokinesis]]. He endorsed the [[spoon bending]] feats of [[Uri Geller]] and other alleged psychics. A 1987 report by the [[National Academy of Sciences|United States National Academy of Sciences]] investigated the paranormal claims of Hasted and chided him for his naiveté for playing into the hands of anyone intending on deceiving him. The report wrote that the conditions of his 1974 tests with Geller did not rule out the possibility of trickery.<ref>[[Kendrick Frazier]]. (1990). ''The Hundredth Monkey and Other Paradigms of the Paranormal''. Prometheus Books. pp. 159–160. {{ISBN|978-0-87975-655-0}}</ref>
Hasted believed that children could paranormally bend paperclips inside a glass sphere, provided the sphere had a hole in it and were allowed to take the sphere into a room unobserved. [[Martin Gardner]] wrote Hasted was incapable of devising simple controls such as videotaping the children secretly.<ref>[[Martin Gardner]]. (1991). ''The New Age: Notes of a Fringe-Watcher''. Prometheus Books. pp. 28-29. {{ISBN|0-87975-644-6}}</ref> Stephen North, a British psychic, was tested by Hasted in the late 1970s. Hasted claimed North had the psychokinetic ability to bend spoons and [[teleportation|teleport]] objects in and out of sealed containers.<ref>John Hasted. (1981). ''The Metal-Benders''. Routledge & Kegan Paul. {{ISBN|0-7100-0597-0}}</ref> North was tested in [[Grenoble]] on 19 December 1977 in scientific conditions and the results were negative.<ref>Marcel Blanc. (1978). [https://books.google.com/books?id=rTTswrb4YRMC&pg=PA431&dq=Jean-Pierre+Girard+psychokinesis&hl=en&sa=X&ei=yH4fU8OaNcHT7AbQ3IHgBQ&ved=0CDcQuwUwAQ#v=onepage&q=Jean-Pierre%20Girard%20psychokinesis&f=false "Fading Spoon Bender"]. ''New Scientist''. p. 431.</ref> According to [[James Randi]], during a test at [[Birkbeck, University of London|Birkbeck College]] North was observed to have bent a metal sample with his bare hands. Randi wrote "I find it unfortunate that [Hasted] never had an epiphany in which he was able to recognize just how thoughtless, cruel, and predatory were the acts perpetrated on him by fakers who took advantage of his naivety and trust."<ref>[[James Randi]]. (1982). Chapter ''Off the Deep End'' in ''[[Flim-Flam! Psychics, ESP, Unicorns, and Other Delusions]]''. Prometheus Books. {{ISBN|0-87975-198-3}}</ref>
The physicist [[John G. Taylor|John Taylor]] gave ''The Metal Benders'' (1981) a negative review. According to Taylor the metal bending tests had poor controls and Hasted was not in the same room as the subjects for some of the tests. Taylor wrote "not only are the tests not watertight but the conjectured theory is monumentally silly." Hasted suggested in the book that paranormal effects arise through telepathy from the individual in a parallel universe.<ref>[[John G. Taylor|John Taylor]]. (1981). [https://books.google.com/books?id=Y_ZOoWgEMvgC&pg=PA438&dq=%22The+Metal+Benders+by+John+Hasted%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=MKUoU_y4H-jX0QXJpYGoAw&ved=0CEcQuwUwAA#v=onepage&q=%22The%20Metal%20Benders%20by%20John%20Hasted%22&f=false "The Metal Benders by John Hasted"]. ''New Scientist''. p. 438.</ref>
==Publications== *''Physics Of Atomic Collisions'' (1964) *''Aqueous Dielectrics'' (1973) *''The Metal Benders'' (1981) *''Alternative Memoirs'' (1992)

==Scientific and academic figures==
===Mathematics, physics and chemistry=== * [[Ahmed ibn Yusuf]] (835–912), mathematician * [[Ibn Tahir al-Baghdadi]] (980–1037), arithmetician * [[Ibrahim ibn Sinan]] (908–946), mathematician and astronomer in Baghdad * [[Al-Uqlidisi]] (920–980), author of two works on arithmetic. He may have anticipated the invention of decimals. * [[Al-Umawi]] (1400–1489), mathematician who wrote works on mensuration and arithmetic. * [[Al-Zarqali]] (1028–1087), influential early [[Islamic mathematics|mathematician]] and [[Islamic astronomy|astronomer]] * [[Ahmed Zewail]] (born 1946) Egyptian-American scientist, winner of the 1999 Nobel Prize in Chemistry<ref>{{cite book|title=International handbook of higher education, Volume 1|editor1-last=Forest|editor1-first=James|editor2-last=Altbach|editor2-first=philip|publisher=Springer|year=2006|page=413|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u3rtCh-EUIIC&pg=PA413#v=onepage&q&f=false|isbn=978-1-4020-4011-5}}</ref> * [[Farouk El-Baz]] (born 1938) Egyptian scientist<ref>{{cite journal|title=الدكتور فاروق الباز : العلماء العرب الذين اختاروا موقع الهبوط على سطح القمر (Dr. Farouk El-Baz: The Arab Scientist Who Selected the Landing Site on the Moon)|language=Arabic|last=Sajd|first=Magdi|journal=علم و عالم (Science and World)|date=December 2003|pages=18–25}}</ref> * [[Charles Elachi]], Lebanese director of the [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] * [[Fawwaz T. This is a '''list of Haitians''', born in [[Haiti]] or possessing Haitian citizenship, notable in Haiti and abroad. Due to [[History of Haitian nationality and citizenship|Haitian nationality laws]], dual citizenship is now permitted by the [[Constitution of Haiti]], therefore people of [[Haitian diaspora|Haitian ancestry born outside of the country]] are not included in this list, unless they have renounced their foreign citizenship or have resided extensively in Haiti and made significant contributions to Haitian government or society. The list includes both native-born and naturalized Haitians, as well as permanent foreign residents who have been recognized internationally for artistic, cultural, economic, historical, criminal, or political reasons, among others. If not indicated here, their birth in Haiti and notability are mentioned in their main article. This list does '''not''' include fictional characters or Haitian associations and organizations. {{rightTOC}} {{dynamic list}} <!--
DO NOT add yourself, non-notable people or fictional characters to this list. You MUST add valid citations from reliable secondary sources (no personal/official websites) showing notability and Haitian birth/ancestry for any names added per [[WP:LISTPEOPLE]] and [[WP:NLIST]]. Any name placed here that doesn't have a Wikipedia article or article section about them, and who doesn't have a referenced statement in their article of their Haitian birth/ancestry will be immediately removed. Please consider using Wikipedia: Requested Articles, instead of this list, for listing notable people without articles, to avoid having otherwise notable names without articles removed from this list. Names without articles, even with references, may be removed if no article is written about them in a timely manner.
Even notable people need to be known OUTSIDE of Haiti for listing at this high level. Otherwise consider listing them under applicable province or municipality. Citation for this high level should be outside of Haiti such as Associated Press, Reuters, London Times, etc.
-->

page.title: List of Naval Ministers of France

revision.text:
One of [[France]]'s '''Secretaries of State''' under the [[ancien régime]] was entrusted with control of the [[French Navy]] ([[Secretary of State of the Navy (France)]]. In 1791, this title was changed to '''Minister of the Navy'''. Before January 1893, this position also had responsibility for [[French colonial empire|France's colonies]], and was usually known as '''Minister of the Navy and Colonies'''. In 1947 the naval ministry was absorbed into the [[Minister of Defence (France)|Ministry of Defence]] and reports to the [[Prime Minister of France]] and the [[President of the French Republic]] at the [[Elysee Palace]].
== History == The two French royal fleets (the [[Ponant fleet]] and [[Levant fleet]]) were put under the control of [[Jean-Baptiste Colbert|Colbert]] from 1662, whilst he was "[[intendant des finances]]" and "minister of state" – but not "secretary of state" : he only became secretary of state in 1669 after having bought his way into the post. From then on, right up to the [[French Revolution]], a secretary of state had responsibility for the fleet.
The secretary of state was responsible for the administration of both the navy (the "marine royale") and civilian (merchant marine) fleets, and for all France's ports, arsenals, consulates, and colonies, as well as the guardianship for all her commercial companies.
To his two original offices (the bureau du Ponant and bureau du Levant) other services were added over time:
*archives department, 1669 ; *office of the [[Ponant fleet|Ponant]] consulates, 1709 ; *office of the colonies, 1710 ; *bureau des classes, 1711 ; *department of maps and plans, 1720 ; *Office of the Levant Consulates, 1738, which was in 1743 merged with the Office of the Ponant Consulates under the name of Office of Commerce and Consulates
These different offices and departments were regrouped into four super-departments by [[marshal of France|marshal]] [[Charles Eugène Gabriel de La Croix de Castries|de Castries]] in 1786.

revision.text:
This is a '''list of notable Zimbabweans'''. This list includes people born in [[Zimbabwe]], notably of Zimbabwean descent, or otherwise strongly associated to Zimbabwe.
== Academics == * [[Gordon Chavunduka]] (1931-2013), sociologist and traditional healer, [[List of principals of the University of Zimbabwe|Vice Chancellor of the University of Zimbabwe]] * [[Fadzayi Mahere]] (born 1985), lawyer and critic of the government, independent candidate in [[Zimbabwean general election, 2018]]
==Artists== * [[Coster Balakasi]] (1972- ), sculptor * [[Dominic Benhura]] (1968- ), sculptor * [[Richard Chiwasa]] (1947- ), sculptor * [[Pfungwa Dziike]] (1972- ), sculptor * [[Charles Fernando]] (1941-1995), artist * [[Onias Mupumha]], sculptor * [[Brian Watyoka]], sculptor
==Businesspeople== * [[John Bredenkamp]] (1940- ), founder of the Casalee Group * [[Phillip Chiyangwa]] (1959- ), founder of the Affirmative Action Group; chair of Native Africa Investments Ltd * [[David Hatendi]] (1953-2012), former CEO of [[MBCA Bank Ltd]] and [[NMB Bank Ltd]], founder of Hatendi Private Equity Advisers * [[Strive Masiyiwa]] (1961- ), founder of telecommunications firm [[Econet Wireless]] and Botswana's Mascom Wireless * [[Mutumwa Mawere]] (1960- ), multi-industrialist * [[Paul Tangi Mhova Mkondo]] (1945-2013), insurance guru, property magnate * [[Trevor Ncube]] (1962- ), newspaper owner * [[Gilbert Peters]] (1988), CEO Spidex * [[Divine Ndhlukula]], founder SECURICO
== Humanitarians == * [[Chido Govera]] (1986- ), campaigner for sustainable farming
== Military personnel == *[[Happyton Bonyongwe]] (1960- ), retired [[major general]] of the [[Zimbabwe National Army]] *[[Constantino Chiwenga]] (1956- ), retired general of the [[Zimbabwe Defence Forces]] and vice president of Zimbabwe since December 2017 *[[Dumiso Dabengwa]] (1939- ), former head of [[Zimbabwe People's Revolutionary Army]] (ZIPRA) intelligence *[[Azim Daudpota]] (1933-2017), [[Pakistan]]i commander of the [[Air Force of Zimbabwe]] *[[Ken Flower]] (died 1987), head of the [[Central Intelligence Organisation]] *[[Ambrose Gunda]] (died 2007), former brigadier general *[[Chenjerai Hunzvi]] (1949-2001), chairman of the [[Zimbabwe National Liberation War Veterans Association]] *[[Alfred Nikita Mangena]] (unknown-1978), commander of ZIPRA *[[Elson Moyo]], former deputy commander of the Air Force of Zimbabwe and key figure in the [[2017 Zimbabwean coup d'état]] *[[Solomon Mujuru]] (1945-2011), commander the [[Zimbabwe Defence Forces]] *[[Perence Shiri]] (1955- ), retired [[Air Chief Marshal]] of the [[Air Force of Zimbabwe]] *[[Jabulani Sibanda]], former ZIPRA soldier, president of the [[Zimbabwe National Liberation War Veterans Association]] *[[Josiah Tongogara]] (1938-1979), commander of [[Zimbabwe African National Liberation Army]] (ZANLA) *[[Josiah Tungamirai]] (1945-2005), military officer and politician *[[Norman Walsh]] (1932/1933-2010), first commander of the Air Force of Zimbabwe *[[Peter Walls]] (1927-2010), first commander of the [[Zimbabwe National Army]], later exiled *[[Vitalis Zvinavashe]] (1943-2009), first commander of the [[Zimbabwe Defence Forces]]
== Musicians == {{main|List of Zimbabwean musicians}}
== Politicians == {{main|List of Zimbabwean politicians}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} {{Dynamic list}} [[File:ItzhakPerlmanWhitehouse2.jpg|thumb | right | [[Itzhak Perlman]], a polio survivor, plays the violin while seated.]] This is a '''list of notable people who have survived paralytic poliomyelitis'''. [[Poliomyelitis]] (often simply called polio) is an acute [[virus|viral]] [[infectious disease|infection]] that involves the [[gastrointestinal tract]] and occasionally the [[central nervous system]]. [[Poliovirus]] is acquired by [[fecal-oral route|faecal-oral]] or oral transmission. Prior to the introduction of a [[polio vaccine|vaccine]] in 1955, infection was common, with [[epidemic]]s during the summer and autumn of [[temperate countries]]. An [[Poliomyelitis eradication|eradication]] programme has reduced the number of reported polio cases worldwide by more than 99% since the mid-1980s. Most infections are [[asymptomatic]]; a small number cause a minor illness that is indistinguishable from many other viral illnesses; less than 1% result in [[acute flaccid paralysis]]. This list only includes notable persons who had the paralytic form of polio. The extent of paralysis varies from part of a limb to [[quadriplegia]] and [[respiratory failure]]. The latter was often treated with an [[Negative pressure ventilator|iron lung]] until, it was hoped, the patient recovered. Around 30–40 years after contracting paralytic poliomyelitis, about 25–40% of cases lead to [[post-polio syndrome]]. Symptoms include muscle pain, further weakening of muscles and paralysis.<ref>{{cite web |vauthors=Alexander L, Watkins M, Alexander J |year=2005–2006 |url=http://www2.ncid.cdc.gov/travel/yb/utils/ybGet.asp?section=dis&obj=polio.htm |title=Yellow Book, Chapter 4, Poliomyelitis |publisher=[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] |accessdate=22 May 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070515190507/http://www2.ncid.cdc.gov/travel/yb/utils/ybGet.asp?section=dis&obj=polio.htm |archivedate=15 May 2007 |df= }} (Public domain text, used with permission and thanks.)</ref><ref>{{cite book | veditors = Atkinson W, Hamborsky J, McIntyre L, Wolfe S | title = Epidemiology and Prevention of Vaccine-Preventable Diseases. | year = 2007 | edition = 10th | publisher = Public Health Foundation | url = https://www.cdc.gov/nip/publications/pink/polio.pdf | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070421152752/http://www.cdc.gov/nip/publications/pink/polio.pdf | archivedate =21 April 2007 | deadurl = yes | format = PDF | chapter = Chapter 8. Poliomyelitis }}</ref>
Surviving paralytic polio can be a life-changing experience. Individuals may be permanently physically [[disability|disabled]] to varying degrees. Others remember the fear and isolation.<ref name=JohnLaws>{{cite news | title = Memories of polio and those who wrestled with it | url = http://www.smh.com.au/news/National/Memories-of-polio-and-those-who-wrestled-with-it/2004/12/06/1102182223039.html | work = The Sydney Morning Herald. | date = 7 December 2004 | accessdate = 18 May 2007 }}</ref> Some continue to campaign for polio eradication or [[disability rights]].
==Uncontested diagnosis==
This categorised alphabetical list contains only those people with a firm and uncontested diagnosis made while still alive.
===Acting===
[[File:MarionDavies-Hat-1920.jpg|150px | thumb | right | Actress [[Marion Davies]] contracted polio as an adult.]] [[File:Donald Sutherland 2014.jpg|150px | thumb | right | Actors [[Donald Sutherland]] (above) and [[Alan Alda]] both played the role of [[Hawkeye Pierce]] and both had polio as children.]]
{| class="sortable wikitable" ! width="22%" | Name ! width="13%" | Life ! class="unsortable" width="65%" | Comments |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Alan|Alda}} | {{sort|1936|born 1936}} | An actor most famous for his role as [[Hawkeye Pierce]] in the television series ''[[M*A*S*H (TV series)|M*A*S*H]]''. Alda contracted polio at age seven, during an epidemic. His parents administered a painful treatment, developed by [[Elizabeth Kenny|Sister Elizabeth Kenny]], in which hot woolen blankets were applied to the limbs and the muscles were stretched by [[massage]].<ref>{{cite interview |subject = Alan Alda |interviewer = [[Tavis Smiley]] |title = Tavis Smiley |url = https://www.pbs.org/kcet/tavissmiley/archive/200412/20041202_alda.html |work = [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] |date = 2 December 2004 |accessdate = 2 May 2007 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070929141115/http://www.pbs.org/kcet/tavissmiley/archive/200412/20041202_alda.html |archivedate = 29 September 2007 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Marion|Davies}} | 1897–1961 | An actress who had a relationship with [[William Randolph Hearst]]. She caught polio in the 1940s, which affected one of her legs.<ref>{{cite web | first = Nick | last = Langdon | url = http://www.decofilms.com/mariondavies/index.htm | title = Marion Davies | publisher = Decofilms.com | accessdate = 18 May 2007 }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|James|Drury}} | {{sort|1934|born 1934}} | Drury is well known for his portrayal of the title role in the weekly television series, ''[[The Virginian (TV series)|The Virginian]]''. He survived a bout of polio at the age of 10.<ref>{{cite web |first = Hal |last = Erickson |url = http://www.allmovie.com/cg/avg.dll?p=avg&sql=2:20216~T1 |title = Biography: James Drury |publisher = Allmovie |accessdate = 18 May 2007 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060426195934/http://www.allmovie.com/cg/avg.dll?p=avg |archivedate = 26 April 2006 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Mia|Farrow}} | {{sort|1945|born 1945}} | An actress who was appointed a [[UNICEF]] goodwill ambassador in 2000, and campaigns in the fight against polio. Farrow collapsed on her ninth birthday and was diagnosed with polio two days later. She was in the hospital for eight months, where an [[Negative pressure ventilator|iron lung]] maintained her breathing.<ref>{{cite interview |subject=Mia Farrow |interviewer=Vince Aversano |title=Mia Farrow uses her star power to shine a light on the fight against polio |url=http://www.rotary.org/newsroom/features/0701_tr_interview.html |work=Rotary International |date=January 2007 |accessdate=5 May 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070106161945/http://www.rotary.org/newsroom/features/0701_tr_interview.html |archivedate=6 January 2007 |df= }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Mel|Ferrer}} | 1917–2008 | In the early 1940s, Ferrer's career as an actor, film director and [[Broadway theater|Broadway]] producer was stalled when he contracted polio. Ferrer was ill for a year and resumed work in radio instead of theatre.<ref>{{cite book |vauthors=Lyon C, Vinson J | title = The International Dictionary of Films and Filmmakers | year = 1986 | publisher = St. James Press | isbn=0-912289-08-2 | pages = 226 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.allmovie.com/artist/mel-ferrer-p23232 | title = Mel Ferrer: Biography | publisher = Allmovie | accessdate = 9 August 2017 }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Phyllis|Kirk}} | 1929–2006 | An actress best known for her role as the heroine in the [[3-D film]] ''[[House of Wax (1953 film)|House of Wax]]''. Kirk had polio as a child.<ref>{{cite news |first=Tom |last=Vallance |title=Obituary: Phyllis Kirk: Heroine of 'House of Wax' |url=http://news.independent.co.uk/people/obituaries/article1919330.ece |work=The Independent |date=23 October 2006 |accessdate=1 June 2007 |location=London |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071001131156/http://news.independent.co.uk/people/obituaries/article1919330.ece |archivedate=1 October 2007 |df= }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Hildegard|Knef}} | 1925–2002 | After a bout with polio in 1932, Knef went on to become an actress, singer and writer.<ref>{{cite web | first = Thomas M. | last = Goerke | url = http://www.hildegardknef.de/1-Hilde%20englisch/Chronology%201925-49.htm | title = Chronology – The life of Hildegard Knef 1925 – 1949 | work = Hildegard Knef Homepage | accessdate = 18 May 2007 }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Ida|Lupino}} | 1918–1995 | A film actress and director, Lupino caught polio in June 1934 and was affected for only a few days.<ref>{{cite book | first = William J. | last = Donati | title = Ida Lupino: A Biography | year = 1996 | publisher = University Press of Kentucky | isbn=0-8131-0982-5 | pages = 29–30 }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Peg|Phillips}} | 1918–2002 | An actress who survived a polio infection she caught as an adult.<ref>{{cite news | first = John | last = Levesque | title = Actress realized her dream on 'Northern Exposure' | url = http://www.seattlepi.com/local/95227_phillips12.shtml | work = Seattle Post-Intelligencer | date = 12 November 2002 | accessdate = 6 May 2007 }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Tim|Rooney}} | 1947–2006 | Actor and [[voice actor]] Tim Rooney was the second son of actor [[Mickey Rooney]]. He contracted polio as a child and was paralysed for two years.<ref>{{cite news | title = Obituary: Timothy Rooney, 59, son of Mickey Rooney | url = http://www.boston.com/news/globe/obituaries/articles/2006/09/28/timothy_rooney_59_son_of_mickey_rooney/ | work = Boston Globe | date = 28 September 2006 | accessdate = 13 June 2007 }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Gianni|Russo}} | {{sort|1943|born 1943}} | An actor best known for his role as Carlo Rizzi in the 1972 movie ''[[The Godfather]]''. He contracted polio at age seven, and spent five years in a state hospital.<ref>{{cite news | first = Andrew | last = Jacobs | title = Mob gofer, actor and now a crooner | url = http://www.iht.com/bin/print_ipub.php?file=/articles/2005/04/12/news/russo.php | work = International Herald Tribune | date = 13 April 2005 | accessdate = 13 June 2007 }} {{dead link|date=April 2018}}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Donald|Sutherland}} | {{sort|1935|born 1935}} | Sutherland contracted polio as a child and developed a love of reading while bedridden. He went on to become an accomplished actor, and has appeared in over 130 films.<ref>{{cite news | first = Steven | last = Kotler | title = Downtime: Donald Sutherland | url = http://www.allbusiness.com/medicine-health/medical-treatments-procedures/9741217-1.html | work = Variety | date = January 2006 | accessdate = 9 October 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Donald Sutherland: Biography | url = http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/donald-sutherland/bio/147781 | work = TV Guide | accessdate = 9 October 2010 }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Phyllis|Thaxter}} | {{sort|1921|1921-2012}} | Thaxter contracted polio in 1952. The disease took a toll on her career as an actress, to which she made a slow return—often taking roles that would accommodate a physical challenge.<ref>{{cite web |first = Hal |last = Erickson |url = http://www.allmovie.com/cg/avg.dll?p=avg&sql=2:70445~T1 |title = Phllis Thaxter: Biography |work = Allmovie |accessdate = 1 June 2007 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060426195934/http://www.allmovie.com/cg/avg.dll?p=avg |archivedate = 26 April 2006 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Gwen|Verdon}} | 1925–2000 | An actress and dancer on Broadway and in films. Verdon was encouraged to dance by her mother, a dance teacher, as therapy for her polio-afflicted legs.<ref>{{cite news | first = Mark | last = Steyn | url = http://archive.spectator.co.uk/article/28th-october-2000/71/cinema | title = Gwen Verdon remembered | work = The Spectator | date = 28 October 2000 | accessdate = 4 July 2007 }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Johnny|Weissmuller}} | 1904–1984 | At age nine, Weissmüller contracted polio. At the suggestion of his doctor, he took up swimming to help battle the disease, and he went on to win five Olympic gold medals in the sport during the 1920s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2008-08-17/news/0808160072_1_johnny-weissmuller |title=From the pool to Hollywood stardom |last=Rasmussen |first=Frederick N. |date=17 August 2008 |publisher=baltimoresun.com |accessdate=15 September 2012}}</ref> |}
===Business=== [[File:Steiffmargarete.jpg|150px | thumb | right | Toymaker [[Margarete Steiff]] was paralysed as an infant.]]
{| class="sortable wikitable" ! width="22%" | Name ! width="13%" | Life ! class="unsortable" width="65%" | Comments |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Daisy Richards|Bisz}} | 1909–2007 | After a bout of polio as an infant, Bisz went on to become one of [[Florida]]'s first female [[Lawyer|attorneys]], eventually winning a number of cases against [[Cuba]]n leader [[Fidel Castro]].<ref>{{cite news | author = Ovalle D | title = Daisy Richards Bisz, 97:Lawyer since '37 led Castro cases | url = http://www.realcities.com/mld/miamiherald/news/obituaries/17214515.htm | work = Miami Herald | date = 12 May 2007 | accessdate = 4 June 2007 }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Richard N.|Cabela}} | {{sort|1936|1936-2014}} | An [[entrepreneur]] and founder of the outdoor retailer [[Cabela's]]. He stated that his business was inspired by his bout with polio and a deep love of fishing and hunting.<ref>{{cite book | first = David | last = Cabela | title = Cabela's: World's Foremost Outfitter | year = 2001 | publisher = P.S. Eriksson | isbn=0-8397-1280-4 }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Pete|Dawkins}} | {{sort|1938|born 1938}} | Former [[Heisman Trophy]] winner, [[Rhodes Scholar]], U.S. Army Brigadier General, and Republican candidate for Senate, Dawkins contracted polio at age eleven.<ref name=NFF_2007>{{cite news |url=http://www.footballfoundation.com/news.php?id=1166 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20070519035618/http://www.footballfoundation.com/news.php?id=1166 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=19 May 2007 |title=NFF Announces 2007 Major Awards Recipients |work=National Football Foundation |date=16 May 2007 |accessdate=25 May 2007 }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Garth|Drabinsky}} | {{sort|1949|born 1949}} | Canadian theatrical producer, contracted polio at age three, and was left with a [[limp]] in his left leg.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.filmreferencelibrary.ca/index.asp?layid=46&csid1=3421&navid=46 |title=Garth H. Drabinsky |accessdate=17 September 2007 |author=Andrew McIntosh |year=2003 |work=Canadian Film Encyclopedia |publisher=Film Reference Library |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929092140/http://www.filmreferencelibrary.ca/index.asp?layid=46&csid1=3421&navid=46 |archivedate=29 September 2007 |df= }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Richard B.|Fisher}} | 1936–2004 | Chairman emeritus of the [[securities]] firm [[Morgan Stanley]], he had to use a cane as a result of polio.<ref name = Globe_2004>{{cite news | author = Bloomberg News | title = Obituary: Richard Fisher, at 68; ex-chairman of Morgan Stanley | url = http://www.boston.com/news/globe/obituaries/articles/2004/12/17/richard_fisher_at_68_ex_chairman_of_morgan_stanley/ | work = Boston Globe | date = 17 December 2004 | accessdate = 26 May 2007 }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Franklin Clarence|Mars}} | 1884–1934 | Founded the [[Mars, Incorporated|Mars]] [[confectionery]] company. This led to selling candy after school and, eventually, his own company.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.practicallyedible.com/edible.nsf/encyclopaedia!openframeset&frame=Right&Src=/edible.nsf/pages/marsfamily!opendocument |title=Mars Family |work=Practically Edible |accessdate=18 May 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090504211100/http://www.practicallyedible.com/edible.nsf/encyclopaedia%21openframeset%26frame%3DRight%26Src%3D/edible.nsf/pages/marsfamily%21opendocument |archivedate=4 May 2009 |df= }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|James McGregor|Stewart}} | 1889-1955 |Prominent Canadian lawyer and businessman. Contracted polio at age two and used crutches. President of the Canadian Bar Association, coal administrator during the Second World War, and founder of Halifax law firm. |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Margarete|Steiff}} | 1847–1909 | A toy maker and founder of the [[Margarete Steiff GmbH|Steiff Company]], known for its [[teddy bear]]. She contracted polio, aged 18 months, and lost the use of her legs and had only partial use of her right arm.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.steiff.de/en/company/geschichte/margarete-steiff.html |title=Margarete Steiff—heart, soul and courage |publisher=Margarete Steiff GmbH |accessdate=8 May 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070223042711/http://www.steiff.de/en/company/geschichte/margarete-steiff.html |archivedate=23 February 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Dennis|Washington}} | {{sort|1934|born 1934}} | A businessman and founder of The Washington Companies. He contracted polio when he was eight and recovered well.<ref>{{cite web |year=2005 |url=http://www.dennisrwashington.com/denniswashingtonbiography.htm |title=Dennis R. Washington—Biography |publisher=Washington Corporations |accessdate=18 May 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070617052621/http://www.dennisrwashington.com/denniswashingtonbiography.htm |archivedate=17 June 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> |- |Wayne E. Nichols Jr. |born 1950 |Business man and founder of Nichols Casework, Inc. and LOC Scientific, Inc, Contracted polio at 3, wore a brace 3 years, 3 surgeries next 10 years. Retired 2014 due to Post Polio Syndrome. |}
===Disability rights activists=== [[File:Heumann.gif|150px | thumb | right | [[Judith Heumann]] had to take legal action to be allowed to become a teacher.]]
{| class="sortable wikitable" ! width="22%" | Name ! width="13%" | Life ! class="unsortable" width="65%" | Comments |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Justin Whitlock|Dart, Jr.}} | 1930–2002 | An [[activist]] who helped pass the [[Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990]]. A bout of polio at age 18 left him using a wheelchair.<ref>{{cite web | first = Mari Carlin | last = Dart | date = 22 June 2002 | url = http://www.abilitymagazine.com/JustinDart_remembered.html | title = The Resurrection of Justin Dart, Jr.: A Quest for Truth and Love | work = Ability Magazine | accessdate = 9 May 2007 }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Theresa|Ducharme}} | 1945–2004 | A crusader for equality of disabled people, Ducharme contracted polio in 1953. The disease left her a quadriplegic and dependent on a respirator for the rest of her life.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.mb.ca/hrc/english/publications/newsletter/bulletin_4_6.pdf |format=PDF |title=Local Activist Remembered |accessdate=7 June 2007 |date=June 2004 |work=Manitoba Human Rights Connections: Newsletter |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930182412/http://www.gov.mb.ca/hrc/english/publications/newsletter/bulletin_4_6.pdf |archivedate=30 September 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Hugh|Gallagher |Hugh Gallagher (advocate)}} | 1933–2004 | Author and [[disability rights]] advocate, Hugh Gallagher contracted polio at college and subsequently required a wheelchair due to lower-body paralysis. He aided the drafting of the [[Architectural Barriers Act of 1968]].<ref>{{cite book | first = Richard | last = Schulz | title = The Encyclopedia of Aging | year = 2006 | publisher = Springer Publishing | isbn=0-8261-4843-3 | pages = 65 }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Judith|Heumann}} | {{sort|1947|born 1947}} | Heumann contracted polio when she was 18 months old, and is unable to walk. She became a disability rights activist, co-founding the World Institute on Disability, and served as Assistant Secretary for Special Education and Rehabilitative Services during the [[Clinton Administration]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.chelseaforum.com/speakers/Heumann.htm | title = Judith E. Heumann | publisher = The Chelsea Forum Inc | accessdate = 12 May 2007 }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Ed|Roberts|Ed Roberts (activist)}} | 1939–1995 | A disability rights activist who co-founded the World Institute on Disability and was the first severely disabled student to attend the [[University of California, Berkeley]]. At age 14 Roberts contracted polio; he was paralysed and in an iron lung within 24 hours. When told he would be a vegetable for the rest of his life, he "decided to be an artichoke...a little prickly on the outside but with a big heart."<ref>{{cite web |first=Ed |last=Roberts |url=http://www.wid.org/about-wid/highlights-from-speeches-by-ed-roberts |title=Highlights from speeches by Ed Roberts |publisher=World Institute on Disability |accessdate=12 May 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070501132735/http://www.wid.org/about-wid/highlights-from-speeches-by-ed-roberts |archivedate=1 May 2007 |df= }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Bert|Massie}} | {{sort|1949|born 1949}} | Sir Bert Massie is a prominent British disability rights campaigner who contracted polio at the age of one. He served as Chairman of the [[Disability Rights Commission]] from 2000 to 2007.<ref name="Bristol - Doctor of Laws">{{cite web|last=Ward|first=Linda|title=Herbert William Massie CBE - Doctor of Laws|url=http://www.bristol.ac.uk/pace/graduation/honorary-degrees/hondeg05/massie.html|accessdate=29 June 2013|date=14 July 2005}}</ref> |}
===Film, television and radio===
[[File:Francis Ford Coppola(CannesPhotoCall).jpg|150px | thumb | right | Director [[Francis Ford Coppola]]'s childhood was interrupted by polio for over a year.]] [[File:Tv city tv david onley 2.jpg|150px | thumb | right | Television presenter [[David Onley]] found his employers to be supportive in accommodating his extra needs.]] {| class="sortable wikitable" ! width="22%" | Name ! width="13%" | Life ! class=unsortable width="65%" | Comments |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Adrian|Adepitan}} | {{sort|1973|born 1973}} | A television presenter and [[wheelchair basketball]] player, Adepitan caught polio, aged six months, in [[Nigeria]]. ==Retrospective diagnosis== [[File:Sir Walter Scott Portrait.jpg|150px | thumb | right | [[Walter Scott|Sir Walter Scott]] may have had the earliest recorded case of polio.]] <!-- [[File:Duc du Maine2.jpg | 150px | thumb | right | Louis Auguste de Bourbon, duc du Maine, 1695.]] --> <!-- [[File:Alice roosevelt color 3.jpg | 150px | thumb | right | Alice Roosevelt (Longworth), taken around her debut in 1902.]] --> The following people were not diagnosed with polio during their lifetime. A [[retrospective diagnosis]] is speculative and can never be certain.
{| class="sortable wikitable" ! width="22%" | Name ! width="13%" | Life ! class="unsortable" width="65%" | Comments |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Claudius|}} | 10 BC – 54 AD | [[Roman Emperor]] from 41 AD to his death. Historians have attributed his physical ailments to several causes. [[Robert Graves]]' Claudius novels made polio a popular choice, but some modern historians prefer [[cerebral palsy]] or some other affliction.<ref>{{cite book | first = Marc | last = Shell | title = Stutter | year = 2005 | publisher = Harvard University Press | isbn=0-674-01937-7 | pages = 187–8 }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Fitz Henry|Lane}} | 1804–1865 | A painter, best known for his paintings of maritime and [[nautical]] subjects (formerly written about as Fitz Hugh Lane). Lane was afflicted with a disorder in childhood, once speculated as being polio, which left him with reduced mobility in his legs.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.huntermuseum.org/FrameForCollections.aspx?page=Include/HTML/Artists/fitzhughlane.htm |title=Fitz Henry Lane |accessdate=31 May 2007 |work=Hunter Museum of American Art |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070811100421/http://www.huntermuseum.org/FrameForCollections.aspx?page=Include%2FHTML%2FArtists%2Ffitzhughlane.htm |archivedate=11 August 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> However the notion that polio was responsible for his childhood of reduced mobility has largely been discredited, for contemporary accounts cite that Lane's paralysis was due to "eating some seeds of the apple peru" (referring either to the common [[tomato]] or to the "peru-apple" also known as [[jimsonweed]]).<ref>{{cite book | author = James A. Craig | title = Fitz H. Lane: An Artist's Voyage Through Nineteenth-century America | publisher = History Press | pages = 17–18 | isbn=1-59629-090-0 | year = 2006 }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Alice Roosevelt|Longworth}} | 1884–1980 | A child of [[Theodore Roosevelt]], the 26th [[President of the United States]], and his first wife, [[Alice Hathaway Lee Roosevelt|Alice Hathaway Lee]]. She wore leg braces as a child and it is believed this was due to polio.<ref>{{cite journal |first=June |last=Bingham |date=June 1969 |title=Before the Colors Fade: Alice Roosevelt Longworth |journal=American Heritage Magazine |volume=20 |issue=2 |url=http://www.americanheritage.com/articles/magazine/ah/1969/2/1969_2_42.shtml |accessdate=24 May 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929122934/http://www.americanheritage.com/articles/magazine/ah/1969/2/1969_2_42.shtml |archivedate=29 September 2007 |df= }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Louis Auguste|de Bourbon}} | 1670–1736 | An illegitimate son of the French [[King Louis XIV]] and [[Madame de Montespan]]. It is thought that Louis-Auguste contracted infantile paralysis (polio) at the age of three which left him with a slight limp.<ref name= Shell/><ref>{{cite book | last = Cronin | first = Vincent | title = Louis XIV | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=yyEaAAAAMAAJ&q=Louis-Auguste+paralysis&dq=Louis-Auguste+paralysis | year = 1965 | publisher = Houghton Mifflin | pages = 296 (snippet) }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Apolinario|Mabini}} | 1864–1903 | The first prime minister of the [[Republic of the Philippines]], it is thought that Mabini contracted polio in 1896; he used a wheelchair for the rest of his life, and came to be known as the "Sublime Paralytic".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nhi.gov.ph/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=64&Itemid=40 |title=Mabini Shrine Tanauan |accessdate=31 May 2007 |work=National Historical Institute |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927012207/http://www.nhi.gov.ph/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=64&Itemid=40 |archivedate=27 September 2007 |df= }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Sir Walter|Scott|Walter Scott}} | 1771–1832 | A [[historical novel]]ist and poet. He caught a fever, aged 18 months, which temporarily paralysed his right leg. Scott was left lame due to his withered leg. At the time, polio was not known to medicine. The retrospective diagnosis of polio is considered to be strong due to the detailed account Scott made.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Cone TE | title = Was Sir Walter Scott's lameness caused by poliomyelitis? | journal = Pediatrics | volume = 51 | issue = 1 | pages = 35 | year = 1973 | pmid = 4567583 }} ([http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/cgi/content/abstract/51/1/35 abstract])</ref><ref>{{cite book | first = Tony | last = Gould | title = A Summer Plague: Polio and its Survivors | year = 1995 | publisher = Yale University Press | isbn=0-300-06292-3 | chapter = Chapter One | chapterurl = http://www.businessweek.com/chapter/gould.htm }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Siptah|}} | reigned 1197 BC – 1191 BC | An [[Ancient Egypt|Egyptian]] [[Pharaoh]]. Siptah's [[mummy]] has a deformed left leg, with the foot held vertically by a shortened [[Achilles tendon]]. Some historians point to polio as a cause, while others prefer a [[congenital defect]] such as [[cerebral palsy]].<ref>{{cite book | first = Aidan | last = Dodson | title = Monarchs of the Nile | year = 2000 | publisher = American University in Cairo Press | isbn=977-424-600-4 | pages = 139 }}</ref> |}
==Doubtful diagnosis== The following people may have had polio, but there is disagreement over it.
[[File:Rooseveltinwheelchair.jpg|150px | thumb | right|[[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] may have contracted polio in 1921, but his symptoms make [[Guillain–Barré syndrome]] more likely.]] {| class="sortable wikitable" ! width="22%" | Name ! width="13%" | Life ! class="unsortable" width="65%" | Comments |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Jean|Chrétien}} | {{sort|1934|born 1934}} | A former [[Prime Minister of Canada]] (1993–2003), Chrétien has a distorted mouth and is [[Hearing impairment|deaf]] in one ear. His condition was possibly caused by [[Bell's palsy]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/1042917.stm |title=Jean Chrétien: Veteran fighter |accessdate=10 July 2007 |work=BBC NEWS | date=28 November 2000}}</ref> or a polio infection as a child.<ref>{{cite book |author1=East, Roger |author2=Thomas, Richard J. | title = Profiles of People in Power: The World's Government Leaders | year = 2003 | publisher = Routledge | isbn=1-85743-126-X | pages = 90 }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Joseph|Goebbels}} | 1897–1945 | A politician in [[Nazi Germany]], one of [[Adolf Hitler]]'s closest associates and minister of propaganda. Biographies differ as to the cause of his "[[club foot]]", which almost certainly was not in fact [[congenital disorder|congenital]]. Some mention a case of [[osteomyelitis]] at age seven, followed by an operation on his left thigh that left the leg three inches shorter than the right. Others attribute it to poliomyelitis at age four. Goebbels, on one occasion, is reported to have blamed a teenage accident.<ref>{{cite book | first = Joseph | last = Goebbels | title = The Early Goebbels Diaries: The Journal of Joseph Goebbels from 1925–1926 | year = 1962 | publisher = Weidenfeld and Nicolson }} Page 18: "Joseph's club-foot. In this respect, too, the two biographies which are based on detailed interrogation of members of the family differ slightly. According to one version, the child, at the age of seven, contracted osteomyelitis and the left thigh had to be operated on" ... "so that the left leg was in the end three inches shorter than the right one. The second version attributes the affliction expressly to poliomyelitis at the age of four. What both explanations have in common is that they describe the deformity as not congenital." Page 137: "His indignation at the article was all the stronger as Dr Goebbels, when asked at the Bayernhof, had told him in so many words that his club-foot had resulted from an accident when he was a schoolboy of thirteen or fourteen."</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Franklin D.|Roosevelt}} | 1882–1945 | The 32nd [[President of the United States]], FDR was stricken with a paralytic illness in 1921, at age 39. His main symptoms were fever; symmetric, ascending paralysis; facial paralysis; bowel and bladder dysfunction; numbness and hyperesthesia; and a descending pattern of recovery. He was left permanently paralyzed from the waist down. FDR was diagnosed with polio at the time, but his symptoms are more consistent with [[Guillain–Barré syndrome]] - an autoimmune neuropathy which his doctors failed to consider as a diagnostic possibility. In 1926, his belief in the benefits of [[hydrotherapy]] led him to found a [[Warm Springs Historic District|rehabilitation center]] at [[Warm Springs, Georgia]]. In 1938, he founded the [[National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis]], leading to the development of polio vaccines. See [[Franklin D. Roosevelt's paralytic illness]] for more information.<ref name="pot-2017"/> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Dmitri|Shostakovich}} | 1906–1975 | A [[composer]] who began to suffer weakness in his right hand in 1958. He was diagnosed with a rare form of polio in 1965, though some contest this diagnosis.<ref>{{cite book | first = David J. | last = Fanning | title = Shostakovich: String quartet no. 8 | year = 2004 | publisher = Ashgate Publishing | isbn=0-7546-0699-6 | pages = 31–2 }}</ref> |}
==Mistakenly believed to have survived polio== [[File:Williamodouglas.jpg|150px | thumb | right | [[William O. Douglas]] claimed to have had polio as a child.]] The following people are often reported to have had polio, but their own statements or other evidence contradict this.
{| class="sortable wikitable" ! width="22%" | Name ! width="13%" | Life ! class="unsortable" width="65%" | Comments |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Bud|Daley}} | {{sort|1932|born 1932}} | A [[Major League Baseball]] pitcher. Commonly reported to be a right-hander who had to learn to play [[southpaw]] after an attack of polio in childhood left his right arm weakened and shortened. Daley instead asserts that his right arm and shoulder were damaged at birth when forceps pinched a nerve. A combination of massage and exercises helped restore his limb to health.<ref>{{cite book | first = Rick | last = Swaine | title = Beating the Breaks: Major League Ballplayers Who Overcame Disabilities | year = 2004 | publisher = McFarland & Company | isbn=0-7864-1828-1 | pages = 192 }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|William O.|Douglas}} | 1898–1980 | A [[United States Supreme Court]] [[Associate Justice]] for thirty-six years. His various memoirs claim that he nearly died from polio shortly before his second birthday. In the book ''Wild Bill: The Legend and Life of William O. Douglas'', biographer [[Bruce Allen Murphy]] argues that it could not have been polio and that this was one of several legends Douglas fabricated.<ref>{{cite web | first = Kit | last = Oldham | date = 15 November 2004 | url = http://www.historylink.org/essays/output.cfm?file_id=7119 | title = Douglas, William O. (1898–1980) | work = HistoryLink.org | accessdate = 19 May 2007 }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|Annette|Kellerman}} | 1887–1975 | A [[Swimming (sport)|swimmer]] and actress. She is often said to have taken up swimming to strengthen her legs after they were weakened by childhood polio.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ishof.org/pdf/history_swimwear.pdf |format=PDF |title=From Bloomer's to Bikini's (sic, recte Bloomers to Bikinis): How the sport of Swimming Changed Western Culture In the 20th Century |work=International Swimming Hall of Fame |accessdate=20 May 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070409181753/http://www.ishof.org/pdf/history_swimwear.pdf |archivedate=9 April 2007 |df= }}</ref> It was, instead, [[rickets]] that caused weakness and bowing and which meant she had to wear leg braces until the age of seven. Kellerman's biography mentions polio on two occasions. Kellerman met President Roosevelt and devised some exercises for him. She also advised Sister [[Elizabeth Kenny]], who became famous for her controversial but popular method of treating polio.<ref>{{cite book | first = Emily | last = Gibson | title = The Original Million Dollar Mermaid: The Annette Kellerman Story | year = 2005 | publisher = Allen & Unwin | isbn=1-74114-432-9 | pages = 4; 12; 76; 97; 190–1 }}</ref> |- valign="top" | {{sortname|John|Thaw}} | 1942–2002 | An actor best known as [[Inspector Morse]]. While it is often speculated that Thaw's characteristic limp was from polio, in truth, the limp originated in childhood, when he would copy his grandfather's limp. A car accident later exaggerated the limp.<ref>{{cite book | author = Sheila Hancock | title = [[The Two of Us: My Life with John Thaw]] | publisher = Bloomsbury USA | year = 2004 | isbn=1-58234-417-5 }}</ref> |}
==Notes== {{Cnote|a|A person permanently dependent upon a [[mechanical ventilator]] to maintain breathing.<ref>[https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/responaut "responaut"]. [[Oxford English Dictionary]]. [[Oxford University Press]]. Retrieved 17 March 2017.</ref>}}

{{Expand French|Louise Ebrel|date=January 2017}} [[File:Ramoneurs de menhirs & Louise Ebrel 50 ans War'l Leur 2017 Quimper 09.jpg|thumb|Louise Ebrel with Loran, punk guitarist of [[Les Ramoneurs de menhirs]].]] '''Louise Ebrel''', born 27 July 1932 at [[Treffrin]] in the [[Côtes-d'Armor|Côtes-du-Nord]] (the present Côtes d'Armor), is a [[Brittany|Breton]] singer whose parents Eugénie Goadec (one of the [[Goadec Sisters]]) and Job Ebrel were themselves singers. Her repertoire is composed of traditional Breton songs, either for dancing (''[[kan ha diskan]]'') or for listening (''[[gwerz]]'').
From 1991 to 2006 she accompanied the singer-poet [[Denez Prigent]] in concerts, both as a duo and with his musical group. Since 1996 she has frequently sung with Ifig Flatrès in ''[[kan ha diskan]]'' at [[fest-noz|festoù noz]]. Since 2006 she has performed on Breton stages with the [[Punk rock|punk]] group [[Les Ramoneurs de menhirs]] and the rockers of [[Red Cardell]] as well as the ensemble [[The Celtic Social Club]] founded in 2014.

{{refimprove|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox murderer |name=Marcelo Costa de Andrade |image= |image_size= |caption= |alt= |birthname=Marcelo Costa de Andrade |alias=The Vampire of Niterói |birth_date={{birth date and age|1967|1|2}} |birth_place=[[Rio de Janeiro]], [[Rio de Janeiro (state)|RJ]], [[Brazil]] |death_date= |death_place= |cause= |conviction= |victims=14 |beginyear=April 1991 |endyear=December 1991 |country=[[Brazil]] |states= |apprehended=December 18, 1991 |imprisoned= }} '''Marcelo Costa de Andrade''' (born January 2, 1967), [[pseudonym|a.k.a.]] "The Vampire of Niterói", is a [[Brazil]]ian [[serial killer]] convicted of raping and killing 14 boys.
==Biography== Marcelo Costa de Andrade was born on January 2, 1967 in [[Rio de Janeiro]], [[Rio de Janeiro (state)|RJ]], [[Brazil]] and grew up in the [[Rocinha]] [[favela]]. He was beaten and sexually abused regularly by the age of ten and began to prostitute himself at the age of fourteen. He was sent to a reform school but later escaped. At 16, Andrade began a relationship with an older man and tried to rape his ten-year-old brother at 17. At 23, he broke up with his lover and moved back in with his family. He found a low-paying job and began to attend the [[Universal Church of the Kingdom of God]].
From April to December 1991, Andrade raped and killed 14 young boys aged 6 to 13. He would lure the boys to secluded spots and rape them, then strangle or beat them to death. He had sex with the corpses and decapitated one of his victims. He believed that doing so would send them to heaven. He also drank some of the victims' blood to "become as beautiful as them".
In December 1991, Andrade encountered ten-year-old Altair Abreu and his six-year-old brother Ivan. They were offered $20 to follow him to a church where he was going to light candles. Andrade then strangled Ivan to death and told Altair that he loved him and had sent Ivan to heaven. Andrade asked Altair to spend the night with him and Altair escaped the next morning after Andrade was going to take him to work with him.
Andrade was arrested on December 18, 1991, and declared insane on April 26, 1993.{{clarify|date=September 2018|reason=Was he tried for criminal offenses? Was he declared guilty or not guilty? Was he acquitted by reason of insanity or was he considered unfit for trial by reason of insanity? I see no mention of a trial or judicial declaration of guilt or innocence in the one cited source.}}
