{{for|the American politician|Victor Garber (politician)}} {{Use Canadian English|date=October 2015}} {{Infobox person | image = VictorGarber2006.JPG | name = Victor Garber | imagesize = | caption = Garber in 2006 | birth_name = Victor Joseph Garber | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1949|03|16}} | birth_place = [[London, Ontario]], Canada | alma_mater = [[University of Toronto]] | occupation = Actor, singer | spouse = {{marriage|Rainer Andreesen|2015}} | residence = [[Southampton, New York]], U.S. | parents = [[Hope Garber|Hope Wolf]]
Joe Garber | years_active = 1958–present }} '''Victor Joseph Garber''' (born March 16, 1949){{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/36/Victor-Garber.html|title=Victor Garber profile at|publisher=FilmReference.com|accessdate=January 15, 2013}} is a Canadian-American [[actor]] and [[singer]]. He is known for playing [[Jesus]] in ''[[Godspell (film)|Godspell]]'', Anthony Hope in ''[[Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street]]'', [[John Wilkes Booth]] in ''[[Assassins (musical)|Assassins]]'', [[Jack Bristow]] in the television series ''[[Alias (TV series)|Alias]]'', Max in ''[[Lend Me a Tenor]]'', [[Thomas Andrews]] in [[James Cameron]]'s ''[[Titanic (1997 film)|Titanic]]'', and [[Kenneth D. Taylor|Ken Taylor]], Canadian Ambassador to Iran, in ''[[Argo (2012 film)|Argo]]''. He was a series regular on ''[[Legends of Tomorrow]]'', as [[Firestorm (comics)|Dr. Martin Stein]], having previously played the same role in a recurring capacity on ''[[The Flash (2014 TV series)|The Flash]]'' as well as the web series ''[[Vixen (web series)|Vixen]]. ==Early life== Garber was born in [[London, Ontario]], and is of [[History of the Jews in Russia|Russian-Jewish]] descent. His parents were father Joseph "Joe" Garber (died 1995), and mother, [[Hope Garber]] (née Bessie Hope Wolf; died 2005), an actress, singer, and the host of ''At Home with Hope Garber''.{{cite news|last=Snook|first=Raven|title=Has Victor Garber found his Tony role?|publisher=Time Out|date=2010-01-13|url=http://newyork.timeout.com/articles/theater/81928/victor-garber-on-his-role-in-present-laughter|accessdate=2010-01-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100122055545/http://newyork.timeout.com/articles/theater/81928/victor-garber-on-his-role-in-present-laughter|archive-date=2010-01-22|dead-url=yes|df=}} He has a brother, Nathan, and a sister, Alisa. Garber began acting at the age of nine, and studied at the [[University of Toronto]]'s [[Hart House (University of Toronto)|Hart House]] at age 16. Garber attended Ryerson Elementary School. He also was enrolled in the children's program of the Grand Theatre; and, at age 16, he was accepted at a six-week summer theatre training program at the [[University of Toronto]] taught by Robert Gill.[https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/theatre/article/750873--victor-garber-jesus-got-the-ball-rolling Profile of Victor Garber], thestar.com; accessed April 24, 2014. ==Career== ===Music=== In 1967, after a period working as a solo [[folk singer]], he formed a [[folk music|folk]] group called [[The Sugar Shoppe]] with Peter Mann, Laurie Hood and Lee Harris. The group enjoyed moderate success, breaking into the Canadian [[Top 40]] with a version of [[Bobby Gimby]]'s song "Canada" (1967).{{cite web |url=http://alextsu.narod.ru/borderlinebooks/canada/s13.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-06-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121120103057/http://alextsu.narod.ru/borderlinebooks/canada/s13.html |archivedate=2012-11-20 |df= }} Three other Sugar Shoppe songs made the lower reaches of the Canadian Top 100 in 1967 and '68, and the band even performed on ''[[The Ed Sullivan Show]]'' and ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson]]'' before breaking up.[http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Pop_Encyclopedia/S/Sugar_Shoppe.html CANOE – JAM! Music – Pop Encyclopedia – Sugar Shoppe] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120526085112/http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Pop_Encyclopedia/S/Sugar_Shoppe.html |date=2012-05-26 }}, jam.canoe.ca; accessed April 24, 2014. ===Theatre=== He played Jesus in Toronto's 1972 production of ''[[Godspell]]''.{{cite web|url=https://godspell1972.wordpress.com/|title=Toronto's Legendary Production of GODSPELL|work=godspell1972.wordpress.com}} In 1985 he appeared in ''[[Noises Off]]'' at the Ahmanson Theatre in Los Angeles.Sullivan, Dan. [http://articles.latimes.com/print/1985-02-12/entertainment/ca-4019_1_dotty-otley "Stage Review : Laughter Is Loudest Part Of 'Noises Off'"] ''Los Angeles Times'', February 12, 1985 He appeared on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] in the original productions of ''[[Deathtrap (play)|Deathtrap]]'', ''[[Sweeney Todd (musical)|Sweeney Todd]]'' and ''Noises Off'' (1983), and in the original [[Off-Broadway]] cast of ''[[Assassins (musical)|Assassins]]'', as well as the 1990s revival of ''[[Damn Yankees]]''. He has been nominated for four [[Tony Award]]s and opened the Tony Awards program in 1994 (the year he was nominated for the Tony Award for ''Damn Yankees'').[https://www.tonyawards.com/en_US/history/ceremonies/200909161253134932312.html "Tony Award 1994"] tonyawards.com, retrieved September 5, 2017 In 1998, he co-starred on Broadway in the Tony Award–winning play ''Art'' with [[Alan Alda]] and [[Alfred Molina]]. In 2005, he played the role of Frederic in the [[Los Angeles Opera]] production of ''[[A Little Night Music]]''. He played Ben in a critically praised [[Encores!]] staged concert production of ''Follies'' (2007) opposite [[Donna Murphy]].Rooney, David. [https://variety.com/2007/legit/reviews/follies-7-1200510463/ "Review: ‘Follies’"] ''Variety'', February 9, 2007 In mid-2007, he played Garry Essendine in a production of [[Noël Coward]]'s ''[[Present Laughter]]'' at Boston's [[Huntington Theatre]].[http://www.huntingtontheatre.org/news/photo/presentl.aspx ''Present Laughter''] huntingtontheatre.org, May 18, 2007. He reprised the role on Broadway in the [[Roundabout Theatre]] production, which opened in January 2010.Jones, Kenneth. [http://www.playbill.com/article/ill-see-you-again-present-laughter-concludes-broadway-run-com-166965# "I'll See You Again": 'Present Laughter' Concludes Broadway Run"] Playbill, March 21, 2010 In January 2018, Garber replaced [[David Hyde Pierce]] as Horace Vandergelder in the Tony-winning Broadway revival of [[Hello, Dolly! (musical)|''Hello, Dolly!'']] at the [[Shubert Theatre (New York City)|Shubert Theatre]] opposite [[Bernadette Peters]]. Garber began performances on January 20 prior to the press opening on February 22.McPhee, Ryan. [http://www.playbill.com/article/bernadette-peters-is-broadways-new-hello-dolly-headliner-beginning-january-20# "Bernadette Peters Is Broadway's New 'Hello, Dolly!' Headliner Beginning January 20"] Playbill, January 20, 2018Stasio, Marilyn. [https://variety.com/2018/legit/reviews/hello-dolly-review-bernadette-peters-1202707835/ "Broadway Review: Bernadette Peters in ‘Hello, Dolly!’"] ''Variety'', February 22, 2018 Garber received the 2018 [[Theatre World Award|Theatre World]] John Willis Award for Lifetime Achievement.Gans, Andrew. [http://www.playbill.com/article/bernadette-peters-and-glenda-jackson-among-presenters-for-2018-theatre-world-awards# "Bernadette Peters and Glenda Jackson Among Presenters for 2018 Theatre World Awards"] ''Playbill'', May 30, 2018 ===Film=== His film work includes [[James Cameron]]'s ''[[Titanic (1997 film)|Titanic]]'' (1997), in which he essayed a [[Ulster English|Mid-Ulster]] accent to play the shipbuilder [[Thomas Andrews]]. Other movie appearances include ''[[Godspell (film)|Godspell]]'' (1973) as [[Jesus]] (the part he originally played in the 1972 Canadian stage production), ''[[Sleepless in Seattle]]'' (1993), ''[[Annie (1999 film)|Annie]]'' (1999), ''[[Legally Blonde]]'' (2001), and ''[[Tuck Everlasting (2002 film)|Tuck Everlasting]]'' (2002). In 2009, he took on the role of the [[DC Comics]] [[supervillain]] [[Sinestro]] in the [[direct-to-video]] [[animated film]] ''[[Green Lantern: First Flight]]''. The same year, Garber played a [[Klingon]] interrogator in [[J. J. Abrams]]' ''[[Star Trek (film)|Star Trek]]'' film; however, his scenes were deleted from the finished film.{{cite news|url=http://trekmovie.com/2009/10/27/star-trek-movie-deleted-klingon-scene-available-online/|publisher=TrekMovie.com|date=2009-10-27|title=Star Trek Movie Deleted Klingon Scene Available Online + DVD/Blu-ray Debuts In Some Countries|accessdate=April 24, 2014}} In 2010, Garber had an uncredited cameo in ''[[The Town (2010 film)|The Town]]'' as a bank manager. The film was directed by ''[[Alias (TV series)|Alias]]'' co-star [[Jennifer Garner]]'s husband, [[Ben Affleck]]. Also Garber had a credited role in the [[Ice Quake (film)|Ice Quake]] at the end of 2010. In late 2012, he appeared in Affleck's film ''[[Argo (2012 film)|Argo]]'', about the [[Iran hostage crisis]]; Garber portrayed Canadian [[Ambassador]] to [[Iran]] [[Kenneth D. Taylor]]. He also co-starred in 2014 thriller [[Big Game (2014 film)|''Big Game'']].[http://bloody-disgusting.com/news/3325509/samuel-jackson-hunts-big-game-poster/ Samuel Jackson Hunts a ‘Big Game’] ===Television=== On television, he has had roles on [[United States|American]] and [[Television in Canada|Canadian]] shows. Garber's first leading role on television show was in [[CBS]]'s 1985 summer series ''[[I Had Three Wives]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/person/68267%7C0/Victor-Garber/biography.html |title=Victor Garber |publisher=[[Turner Classic Movies|Turner Classic Movies (TCM)]] |date= |accessdate=2017-06-23 |quote=He landed his first leading role in a series with "I Had Three Wives" (CBS, 1985), playing a private investigator who receives help from a trio of ex-wives (Shanna Reed, Teri Copley and Maggie Cooper).}} He had a recurring guest role on [[CTV Television Network|CTV]]'s ''[[E.N.G.]]'' (1991–93). He portrayed Jack Bristow on ABC's show, ''[[Alias (TV series)|Alias]]'', earning three Emmy nominations. He next starred on the television series ''[[Justice (2006 TV series)|Justice]]'' (2006) on [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] and ABC's ''[[Eli Stone]]''. He appeared as Olivier Roth in four episodes of the Canadian science drama ''[[ReGenesis]]''. He appeared in Episode 3 of the Fox series ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]'' as Will's father. He played [[Firestorm (comics)|Dr. Martin Stein / Firestorm]] on ''[[The Flash (2014 TV series)|The Flash]]'' beginning in 2015 and appeared as the character in a regular role on ''[[Legends of Tomorrow]]'' until 2017 and has the recurring role of Admiral Halsey on ''[[The Orville]]''. ==Personal life== Garber prefers to keep his personal life private and has largely stayed out of the [[Tabloid journalism|tabloids]]. He [[Coming out|referred publicly]] to his homosexuality in 2012. In 2013, he said "I don't really talk about it, but everybody knows."{{cite news|first=Christie|last=D'Zurilla|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/gossip/la-et-mg-victor-garber-gay-rainer-andreesen-20130115,0,7000496.story|title=Victor Garber's gay, he confirms — but didn't you know already?|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=January 15, 2013|accessdate=January 15, 2013}} Garber has been in a relationship with Canadian artist and model Rainer Andreesen since 2000.{{cite web|url=http://www.foreveryoungnews.com/articles/victor-victorious-victor-garber-on-success-family-and-friends/|title=Victor Victorious: Victor Garber on success, family and friends|last=Drucker|first=Hal|date=April 13, 2012|work=Forever Young Information|accessdate=January 15, 2013}} On October 10, 2015, Andreesen announced on his Instagram page that he and Garber were married in Canada.{{cite web|url=https://instagram.com/p/8qSubIMvB4/|title=rainerarts: YES WE DID! #justgotmarried #elopedintofino #canada @therealvictorgarber #after16years|last=Andreesen|first=Rainer|date=October 10, 2015|work=Instagram|accessdate=October 12, 2015}} Victor and Rainer reside in [[Southampton, New York]].{{fact|date=November 2018}} Victor has [[Type 1 diabetes]] he was diagnosed in 1962 when he was 12 years old https://www.diabetesdaily.com/blog/interview-actor-victor-garber-doesnt-let-type-1-diabetes-define-him-390506/ ==Filmography== ===Film=== {|class="wikitable sortable" width="100%" ! [[Malecite-Passamaquoddy language|Malecite-Passamaquoddy]]
[[Mi'kmaq language|Mi'kmaq]]
[[English language|English]]
[[French language|French]] |religion = Traditional [[First Nations]] and [[Native American religion]]s
[[Christianity]] |currency = [[Wampum]] |today = {{flagcountry|USA}}
{{flagcountry|Canada}} |stat_year1 = 1606 |stat_area1 = 349405 |stat_pop1 = |stat_year2 = |stat_area2 = |stat_pop2 = |stat_year3 = |stat_area3 = |stat_pop3 = |stat_year4 = |stat_area4 = |stat_pop4 = |stat_year5 = |stat_area5 = |stat_pop5 = }} The '''Wabanaki Confederacy''' (''Wabenaki, Wobanaki'', translated roughly as "People of the First Light" or "People of the Dawnland") are a [[First Nations]] and [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] confederation of five principal nations: the [[Mi'kmaq]], [[Maliseet]], [[Passamaquoddy]], [[Abenaki]], and [[Penobscot]]. Members of the Wabanaki Confederacy, the '''Wabanaki peoples''', are in and named for the area which they call ''Wabanahkik'' ("Dawnland"), generally known to [[Europe|European]] settlers as [[Acadia]]. It is made up of most of present-day [[Maine]] in the United States, and [[New Brunswick]], mainland [[Nova Scotia]], [[Cape Breton Island]], [[Prince Edward Island]] and some of [[Quebec]] south of the [[St. Lawrence River]] in Canada. The Western Abenaki live on lands in [[New Hampshire]], [[Vermont]], and [[Massachusetts]] of the United States.Toensing, Gale Courey. [http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/node/93141 "Sacred fire lights the Wabanaki Confederacy"]{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, ''Indian Country Today'' (June 27, 2008), ICT Media Network In recent official statements, the Confederacy has emphasized common cause with, and acceptance of, alliances with environmental activists toward the goal of protecting their land and waters. They gained powers under the United Nations 2010 [[Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples]] (DRIP) and related treaties which major powers have signed.Howe, Miles. [http://halifax.mediacoop.ca/story/rebuilding-wabanaki-confederacy/12494 "Rebuilding the Wabanaki Confederacy"], ''Halifax Media Co-op'' (September 3, 2012). ==History== The confederacy has historically united five North American [[Algonquian languages|Algonquian language]]-speaking [[First Nations]] peoples. It played a key role in supporting the colonial rebels of the [[American Revolution]] via the [[Treaty of Watertown]], signed in 1776 by the [[Mi'kmaq]] and [[Passamaquoddy]], two of its constituent tribes. Under this treaty, Wabanaki soldiers from [[Canada]] are still permitted to join the [[United States|US]] [[United States Armed Forces|military]]. They have done so in 21st-century conflicts in which the US has engaged, including the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–14)|Afghanistan War]] and the [[Iraq War]]. Members of the Wabanaki Confederacy are: * ''(Eastern) [[Abenaki]]'' or ''Penawapskewi'' ([[Penobscot]]) * ''(Western) [[Abenaki]]'' * ''Míkmaq'' ([[Mi'kmaq people|Mi'kmaq]], L'nu, or Micmac) * ''Pestomuhkati'' ([[Passamaquoddy]]) * ''Wolastoqiyik'' ([[Maliseet]] or Malicite) Nations in the Confederacy are also closely allied with the [[Innu]] and [[Algonquin people|Algonquin]] and with the [[Iroquoian]]-speaking [[Wyandot people|Wyandot]]. Wabanaki were also allies of the [[Wyandot people|Huron]] in the past. Together they jointly invited the colonization of [[Quebec City]] and [[LaHave, Nova Scotia|LaHave]] and the formation of [[New France]] in 1603, in order to put French guns, ships, and forts between themselves and the powerful [[Mohawk people]] to the west. Today the only remaining Huron [[First Nation]] resides mostly in the suburbs of [[Quebec City]], a legacy of this protective alliance. The Wabanaki ancestral homeland stretches from Newfoundland, Canada to the [[Merrimack River]] valley in New Hampshire and Massachusetts, United States. This became a hotly contested borderland between the English of colonial New England and French Acadia following the European settlement in the early 17th century. Members of the Wabanaki Confederacy of Acadia participated in six major wars, beginning with [[King William's War]] in 1688, before the British defeated the French in North America: *[[King William's War]] (1688–1697) *[[Queen Anne's War]] (1702–1713) *[[Dummer's War]] (1722–1725) *[[King George's War]] (1744–1748) *[[Father Le Loutre's War]] (1749–1755) *[[French and Indian War]] (1754–1763) During this period, their population was radically decimated due to many decades of warfare, but also because of famines and devastating epidemics of [[infectious disease]].Prins, Harald E.L., and McBride, Bunny, [http://www.nps.gov/acad/historyculture/ethnography.htm "Asticou's Island Domain: Wabanaki Peoples at Mount Desert Island 1500–2000]," (National Park Service, 2007) Wabanaki people freely intermarried with French [[Catholics]] in Acadia starting in 1610 after the conversion of Chief [[Henri Membertou]]. After 1783 and the end of the American Revolutionary War, [[Black Canadians|Black Loyalists]], [[freedmen]] from the British colonies, were resettled by the British in this historical territory. They had promised slaves freedom if they left their rebel masters and joined the British. Three thousand freedmen were evacuated to Nova Scotia by British ships from the colonies after the war. Many intermarriages occurred between these peoples, especially in southwest Nova Scotia from [[Yarmouth, Nova Scotia|Yarmouth]] to [[Halifax (former city)|Halifax]]. Suppression of Acadian, Black, Mi'kmaq, and [[Irish Canadian|Irish]] people under British rule tended to force these peoples together as allies of necessity. Some white and black parents abandoned their [[mixed-race]] children on reserves to be raised in Wabanaki culture, even as late as the 1970s.{{cn|date=March 2018}} The British declared the Wabanaki Confederacy forcibly disbanded in 1862. However the five Wabanaki nations still exist, continued to meet, and the Confederacy was formally re-established in 1993. == Contemporary== The Wabanaki Confederacy gathering was revived in 1993. The first reconstituted confederacy conference in contemporary time was developed and proposed by Claude Aubin and Beaver Paul and hosted by the Mi'kmaq community of [[Listuguj]] under the leadership of Chief Brenda Gideon Miller. The sacred Council Fire was lit again, and embers from the fire have been kept burning continually since then. The revival of the Wabanaki Confederacy brought together the Passamaquoddy Nation, Penobscot Nation, Maliseet Nation, the Mi'kmaq Nation, and the Abenaki Nation Following the 2010 UN DRIP declaration (Declaration of Rights of Indigenous Peoples),{{cite web|author= |url=http://bangordailynews.com/2010/12/19/news/bangor/wabanaki-tribes-cheer-un-declaration-that-defends-their-rights/ |title=Wabanaki tribes cheer UN declaration that defends their rights |work=Bangor Daily News — BDN Maine |publisher=Bangordailynews.com |date=2010-12-19 |accessdate=2016-06-27}} the tribes began to assert their rights as defined in it. They invited non-Indian people to participate in the Confederacy meetings, especially [[environmental activist]]s. The Wabanaki leadership emphasized the continuing role of the Confederacy in protecting [[natural capital]]. Some key quotes from leading participants:
"When we talk about Wabanaki people, we're also talking about Wabanaki people being the land, being the trees, being the animals, because in that cultural perspective, we're all related...The Wabanaki are in a far better position to defend the land," says gkisedtanamoogk. "No land was ever ceded, and that's acknowledged by both the province and the federal government. So on the basis of the treaties, what we're suggesting is that you and I have a common responsibility to the land under those treaties." – gkisedtanamoogk, the Gathering's fire keeper.
"Within the Wabanaki territory we're looking for allies that are going to stand against the total annihilation of our land and water and air. We're looking for allies who will help us to put our nation back together, and put it back in order. And we're asking our allies to help us empower that. And in the process of doing that, they will be decolonizing us and they will be decolonizing themselves." – Jeaba-weay-quay (roughly translated from Obijway to 'The woman whose voice pierces').
"We're going to rebuild the Wabanaki Confederacy," says LaPorte. "We also invited some non-Natives...to come and be with us and to help us build an alliance, so that when we...come into conflict with the government and some of their decisions and policies...to have them stand beside us and to let their government know that it's not only Native people who are worried about the water, the land, the air. But it's also people from their nation that are concerned." – Harry LaPorte, grand chief of the [[Maliseet]] First Nation
The final press release indicated that "the grandmothers" would decide the next step in reconstructing the confederacy as a legal and sovereign entity. The structure resembles that of [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Indigenous Peoples]] in [[Chiapas]]. [[Subcomandante Marcos]] and other political and military leaders better known to the public there have formally recognized the authority of the "comandantes" (older Indigenous women). There were meetings amongst allies,{{cite web|url=http://mainewabanakireach.org/ally/ |title=Ally |publisher=Maine-Wabanaki REACH |date= |accessdate=2016-06-27}} a "Water Convergence Ceremony" in May 2013,{{cite web|url=http://nationtalk.ca/story/wabanaki-water-convergence-ceremony-kairos |title=Wabanaki Water Convergence ceremony – Kairos |website=Nationtalk.ca |date=2013-05-31 |accessdate=2016-06-27}} with [[Algonquin people|Algonquin]] grandmothers in August 2013 supported by [[Kairos Canada]],{{cite web|url=http://www.kairoscanada.org/kairostimes/kairostimes-13-10.html |title=Kairos Times: October 2013 |website=Kairoscanada.org |date=2013-10-15 |accessdate=2016-06-27}}{{cite web|url=http://nationtalk.ca/story/letter-from-algonquin-grandmothers-attending-wabanaki-confederacy-conference |title=Letter from Algonquin Grandmothers, attending Wabanaki Confederacy Conference |website=Nationtalk.ca |date=2013-10-11 |accessdate=2016-06-27}} and with other indigenous groups. [[Alma Brooks]] represented the Confederacy at the June 2014 [[UN Permanent Forum on Indigenous Issues]].{{cite web|last=Warden |first=Rachel |url=http://rabble.ca/blogs/bloggers/kairos-canada/2014/06/indigenous-women-unite-un-permanent-forum-on-indigenous-issues |title=Indigenous women unite at UN Permanent Forum on Indigenous Issues |website=Rabble.ca |date=2014-06-06 |accessdate=2016-06-27}} She discussed the Wabanaki/Wolostoq position on the [[Energy East]] pipeline.{{cite web|url=http://nbmediacoop.org/2013/10/14/energy-east-pipeline-poses-enormous-threat-to-environment-advocates-for-renewable-energy-hold-parallel-summit |title=“Energy East pipeline poses ‘enormous threat’ to environment:” Advocates for renewable energy hold parallel summit |publisher=NB Media Co-op |date=2013-10-14 |accessdate=2016-06-27}} Opposition to its construction has been a catalyst for organizing: :"On May 30 [2015], residents of [[Saint John, New Brunswick|Saint John]] will join others in [[Atlantic Canada]], including Indigenous people from the Wolastoqiyik (Maliseet), Passamaquoddy and Mi'kmaq, to march to the end of the proposed pipeline and draw a line in the sand." This was widely publicized.{{cite web|url=https://ricochet.media/en/455/the-stories-of-energy-east-in-new-brunswick |title=The stories of Energy East in New Brunswick | Ricochet |website=Ricochet.media |date= |accessdate=2016-06-27}} ===2015 Grandmothers' Declaration=== These and other preparatory meetings set an agenda for the August 19–22, 2015, meeting{{cite web|url=http://www.abenakitribe.org/uploads/wabanakiconfederacy2015flyer.pdf|format=PDF|title=WABANAKI CONFEDERACY CONFERENCE|date=August 2015|website=Abenakitribe.org|accessdate=2016-06-27}} which produced the promised Grandmothers' Declaration{{cite web|url=http://willinolanspeaks.com/shares/peoples-lawsuit-related-media-coverage/peoples-lawsuit-plaintiffs-present-to-nb-fracking-commission/wabanaki-confederacy-conference-statement-2015/ |title=Wabanaki Confederacy Conference Statement 2015 |website=Willinolanspeaks.com |date= |accessdate=2016-06-27}} "adopted unanimously at N'dakinna ([[Shelburne, Vermont|Shelburne, VT]]) on August 21, 2015". The Declaration included mention of: *Revitalization and maintenance of indigenous languages *Article 25 of the [[United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples]] on land, food and water *A commitment to "establish decolonized maps" *The [[Wingspread Statement]] on the [[Precautionary Principle]]s *Obligation of governments to "obtain free, prior, and informed consent" before "further infringement" *A commitment to "strive to unite the Indigenous Peoples; from coast to coast", e.g. against [[Tar Sands]]. *Protecting food, "seeds, waters and lands, from chemical and genetic contamination" *Recognizes and confirms the unique decision-making structures of the Wabanaki Peoples in accordance with Article 18 of the UN DRIP indigenous decision-making institutions: **"Our vision is to construct a Lodge, which will serve as a living constitution and decision-making structure for the Wabanaki Confederacy." *Recognizes the Western Abenaki living in Vermont and the United States as a "People" and member nation *Peace and friendship with "the Seven Nations of [[Iroquois]]" === Position on ecological and health issues === On October 15, 2015, Alma Brooks spoke to the New Brunswick Hydrofracturing Commission, applying the Declaration to current provincial industrial practices:{{cite web|url=http://www.willinolanspeaks.com/shares/?p=1124 |title=Alma Brooks: Statements to New Brunswick Hydrofracturing Commission Oct 2015 |website=Willinolanspeaks.com |date=2013-10-18 |accessdate=2016-06-27}} *She criticized the "industry of [[hydro-fracturing]] for natural gas in our territory" because "our people have not been adequately consulted... have been abused and punished for taking a stand," and cited traditional knowledge of floods, quakes and salt lakes in New Brunswick; *Criticized [[J. D. Irving|Irving Forestry Companies]] for having "clear cut our forests [and] spraying poisonous carcinogenic herbicides such as [[glyphosate]] all over 'our land', to kill hardwood trees, and other green vegetation," harming human and animal health: *Noted "Streams, brooks and creeks are drying up; causing the dwindling of [[Atlantic salmon]] and trout. Places where our people gather medicines, hunt deer and moose is being contaminated with poison. We were not warned about the use of these dangerous herbicides; but since then cancer rates have been on the rise in Maliseet Communities; especially [[breast cancer]]s in women and younger people are dying from cancer." *[[Open pit mining]] "for [[tungsten]] and [[molybdenum]] [which] require [[tailing pond]]s; this one designated to be the largest in the world [which] definitely will seep out into the environment. A spill or leak from the [[Sisson Brook]] open pit mine will permanently contaminate the [[Nashwaak River]]; which is a tributary of the Wolastok ([[Saint John River (Bay of Fundy)|St. John River]]) and surrounding water ways. This is the only place left clean enough for the survival of the [[Atlantic salmon]]." *"[[Oil pipeline]]s and "refineries ... bent on contaminating and destroying the very last inch of (Wəlastokok) Maliseet territory." *Rivers, lakes, streams, and lands.. contaminated "to the point that we are unable to gather our annual supply of [[fiddlehead]]s [an edible fern], and medicines." *The "duty to consult with aboriginal people...has become a meaningless process,"... "therefore governments and/or companies do not have our consent to proceed with hydro-fracturing, open pit mining, or the building of pipelines for gas and oil bitumen." === 2016 === The Passamaquoddy will host the 2016 Wabanaki Confederacy Conference. =="Wabanaki Confederacy" in various indigenous languages== The term ''Wabanaki Confederacy'' in many [[Algonquian languages]] literally means "Dawn Land People". {| class="wikitable" |- ! {{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{multiple issues| {{COI|date=March 2014}} {{autobiography|date=March 2014}} {{ambox|issue=This article's subject '''may not meet Wikipedia's inclusion criteria''' as described at WP:AUTHOR.|date=March 2014 | text=See [[Talk:Wena Poon]] for more information on the above issues.}} }}
'''Wena Poon''' (方慧娜, born 1974)<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://ssa1207fcemigrantliterature.wordpress.com/wena-poon/|title=Wena Poon|date=2014-11-03|work=SSA1207FC: Nationality, Identity and Singaporean Literature|access-date=2018-01-29|language=en-US}}</ref> is a lawyer and novelist<ref>{{cite web|url=http://publishingperspectives.com/2009/11/singapore-showcases-homegrown-literary-talent/ |title=Singapore Showcases Homegrown Literary Talent |publisher=Publishing Perspectives |date=19 November 2009 |accessdate=15 March 2014}}</ref> based in the United States.<ref>{{cite book|last=Xu|first=Wenying|title=Historical Dictionary of Asian American Literature and Theater|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZL6a3CiaHBEC&pg=PA219|accessdate=15 March 2014|year=2012|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=978-0-8108-5577-9}}</ref> She writes English-language fiction. Her work has been seen by academics in the UK, US and Singapore as representative of the [[transnationalism]]<ref>{{cite book|last=Howard|first=Michael C.|title=Transnationalism and Society: An Introduction|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Qy4YtuIHsQcC&pg=PA281|date=28 February 2011|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-0-7864-8625-0|pages=281–}}</ref> of her generation.<ref>Chang, Stewart. 'Flexible Citizenship' in Wena Poon's Short Stories: Writing at the Interstices of Asia and America. Southeast Asian Review of English 50 (2012): 47–58.</ref><ref>Awadalla, M. and March-Russell, P. et al. [[The postcolonial short story : contemporary essays]].New York : Palgrave Macmillan, 2013.</ref>
==Biography==
Poon began writing novels and plays in her early teens<ref>{{cite web|url=http://goodbooksguide.blogspot.com/2008/03/words-come-easy-to-wena-poon.html |title=Eric Forbes's book addict's guide to good books: Words come easy to Wena POON |publisher=Goodbooksguide.blogspot.com |date=17 March 2008 |accessdate=15 March 2014}}</ref>{{Unreliable source?|date=March 2014}}. She obtained her degrees in English literature and law from [[Harvard University]]. She is a corporate finance lawyer by profession. Born and raised in Singapore, she has lived in Hong Kong, New York, [[Boston]], San Francisco and [[Austin]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.overseassingaporean.sg/articles/d/wena-poon-new-york-texas-us |title=Wena Poon, New York & Texas, US |publisher=Overseas Singaporean |accessdate=15 March 2014}}</ref> Her family is of Chinese Teochew descent and has lived in Singapore for five generations. According to Poon her grandmother and the story of her family as well as her home country during [[World War II|WWII]] served as a major inspiration to her as a writer.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/culture/2014/08/23/books/wena-poon-life-death-occupied-kyoto/|title=Wena Poon on life and death in occupied Kyoto {{!}} The Japan Times|work=The Japan Times|access-date=2018-01-29|language=en-US}}</ref> She speaks English, French, [[Modern Standard Mandarin|Mandarin]], [[Teochew dialect|Teochew]], [[Cantonese]] and [[Hokkien]] {{clarify|date=September 2017}} and reads [[Japanese writing system|Japanese]] script. These languages are sometimes used in her English-language fiction. She claimed that she had grown up with multilingual radio broadcasts and television series including [[M*A*S*H (TV series)|M*A*S*H]]. Poon herself described her childhood as "audio-visual". She is a photography enthusiast and has incorporated some of her photographs as illustration to her novella "Kami and Kaze". Poon is also a fan of [[anime]], [[manga]] as well as the works of the film director and actor [[Takeshi Kitano]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/culture/2014/08/23/books/wena-poon-life-death-occupied-kyoto/#.Wm9N7rxl-01|title=Wena Poon on life and death in occupied Kyoto {{!}} The Japan Times|work=The Japan Times|access-date=2018-01-29|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Literary prizes ==
Since her first book was released in 2008, Poon has won the Willesden Herald Short Story Prize (UK), and has been nominated for the [[Frank O'Connor]] Award (Ireland), Le Prix Hemingway (France), the [[Bridport Prize|Bridport Prize in Poetry]] (UK), the [[Singapore Literature Prize]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://singaporebookcouncil.wordpress.com/category/nbdcs/page/18/ |title=NBDCS Page 18 |publisher=Singapore Book Council |date=27 August 2010 |accessdate=15 March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bookcouncil.sg/images/uploads/awards/SLP-2008.pdf |title=The Singapore Literature Prize 2008 |publisher=Book Council |format=PDF |accessdate=15 March 2014}}</ref> and the Popular Readers Award (Malaysia).
==Short fiction collections== ''[[Lions in Winter]]'' (2007) portrays the Singapore Chinese diaspora in America, Canada, Australia and England.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.qlrs.com/critique.asp?id=620 |title=Criticism : A Singaporean Diaspora? |publisher=QLRS |date=April 2008 |accessdate=15 March 2014}}</ref> It was published in the US and Europe by Salt Publishing London and in Asia by [[MPH Group|MPH Group Publishing]]. It was a [[Straits Times]] best-seller in Singapore,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article/straitstimes20080203-1.2.48.6.8.aspx |title=Newspaper Article – BESTSELLERS |publisher=Newspapers.nl.sg |accessdate=15 March 2014}}</ref> was longlisted for the 2008 [[Frank O'Connor International Short Story Award]]<ref>{{cite web|title=The Frank O'Connor International Short Story Award|url=http://www.munsterlit.ie/FOC%20Award%20page.html|website=Munster Literature Center|accessdate=20 July 2017}}</ref> and shortlisted for the 2008 [[Singapore Literature Prize]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Wena Poon, New York & Texas, US|url=https://www.overseassingaporean.sg/articles/d/wena-poon-new-york-texas-us|website=Overseas Singaporean Unit|accessdate=20 July 2017}}</ref>
In 2009, Poon released ''The Proper Care of Foxes''. Using Voltaire's "Il fault cultiver notre jardin" as a theme, the stories take place in Singapore, Hanoi, Hong Kong, London, New York, and Palo Alto. The title story is about a high-flying young London banker who was laid off during the recession and his chance encounter with an old classmate from Malaysia. Published by Ethos Books, it earned her a second longlist nomination for the [[Frank O'Connor International Short Story Award]] and another nomination for the Singapore Literature Prize.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.asiaone.com/print/News/Latest%2BNews/Showbiz/Story/A1Story20100624-223724.html |title=Asiaone – S'pore firm offers |publisher=News.asiaone.com |date=24 June 2010 |accessdate=15 March 2014}}</ref>
In 2013, Poon released ''Maxine, Aoki, Beto + Me'', her third short fiction collection featuring stories and her black and white photographs from around the world. Most of the stories have been previously published in international literary anthologies<ref>{{cite web|url=http://asiancha.blogspot.com/2011/07/wena-poon-and-blair-reeve-in-asia.html |title=: Wena Poon and Blair Reeve in Asia Literary Review |publisher=Asiancha.blogspot.com |date=7 July 2011 |accessdate=15 March 2014}}</ref> and journals in 2010–2012, including "The Architects", winner of the Willesden Herald Prize in London<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.willesdenherald.com/competition/previousyears.php |title=The Willesden Herald short story competition – Previous years |publisher=Willesden Herald |accessdate=15 March 2014}}</ref> and "Dialogue Between Novillera and Minotaur", shortlisted for the Prix Hemingway in France.
==Theater== Poon's novel ''Alex y Robert'' was commissioned by a Singapore theatre director originally for the stage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.palgrave.com/products/title.aspx?pid=478556 |title=Writing a First Novel | Karen Stevens | Palgrave Macmillan |publisher=Palgrave.com |date=27 January 2014 |accessdate=15 March 2014}}</ref> It was acquired by [[BBC Radio 4]] and made into a 10 episode radio drama starring veteran BBC American actress [[Lorelei King]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00tl4h6 |title=BBC Radio 4 – Book at Bedtime, Alex y Robert, Episode 1 |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=6 September 2010 |accessdate=15 March 2014}}</ref> A short story spinoff from ''Alex y Robert'', ''Dialogue Between Novillera & Minotaur'', was translated in French and performed in the ancient Roman amphitheater in [[Nimes]], France. It was shortlisted for France's Hemingway Prize and later published by Avocats du Diable in a French anthology called ''Pas De Deux'' (September 2011).
Poon's great-granduncle was the head of a Chinese [[Teochew people|Teochew]] opera troupe in [[Malaysia]] during the golden era of [[Chinese opera]] in the 1930s. Poon incorporated Teochew opera in her latest English play ''The Wood Orchid'', which was performed at [[Westminster Abbey]], London, as part of the [[Bush Theatre]]'s October 2011 project "[[Sixty Six Books]]". The authentic Chinese opera costumes in the play were sourced from Manchester. The play is for 4 actors, based upon a chapter of the [[King James Bible]].<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.bushtheatre.co.uk/sixtysix/ |title=Sixty Six Books |accessdate=6 May 2012 }}</ref> The title refers to [[Hua Mulan]], the Chinese woman warrior. The play was published by [[Oberon Books]] London in a book called ''66 Books: 21st Century Writers speak to the King James Bible'' (October 2011).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oberonbooks.com/66-books |title=Sixty-Six Books | Bush Theatre a contemporary response to the King James Bible Bush Theatre |publisher=Oberon books |accessdate=15 March 2014}}</ref>
==Novels==
In 2016, Poon released 4 new novels, among which are "Chang'an: A Story of China & Japan" (長安）, about a Mandarin-speaking Japanese army doctor who hides in Communist China for decades as a Chinese man, and "Shonanto no Ramen" （吃麵民族）, about the shared love of ramen noodles between the Chinese and the Japanese, set against the backdrop of war during the Japanese Occupation of Singapore. The novels explore the history of China and Japan's intimate but fractious relationship.
Poon is bilingual and writes in English. However, "Shonanto no Ramen" is her first book written in both English and Chinese.
In 2015, Poon published a novel, "Cafe Jause: A Story of Viennese Shanghai", about a Viennese cafe run by Hungarian and Viennese Jews in 1936 Shanghai. It was launched at the China Bookworm Literary Festival in Beijing, Chengdu and Suzhou. In 2014, Poon released a novel called "Kami and Kaze" (神と風). Set in 1948 Kyoto, the novel is about the [[American occupation of Japan]] and the relationship between an Allied administrator, Kate Schroeder, and her young Japanese driver, Nakamura Shinji. It examines white racism against the Japanese and the power of the words "[[kamikaze]]" in the Western imagination.
Poon's 2010 novel, ''Alex y Robert'', is a 21st-century novel about a young woman from [[Texas]] who goes to Spain to break into the male-dominated world of [[bullfighting]].<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.saltpublishing.com/books/smf/9781844717699.htm |title=Wena Poon: Alex y Robert |accessdate=6 May 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://gweek.wordpress.com/2010/07/20/wena-poon-talks-bull/#more-3323 |title=Wena Poon Talks Bull! | Gweek Culture: World of Terrifying Secret Opinions |publisher=GGweek Culture |date=20 July 2010 |accessdate=15 March 2014}}</ref>{{Unreliable source?|date=March 2014}}It was adapted by [[BBC Radio 4]] for serialisation over two weeks for its ''[[Book at Bedtime]]'' radio show.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00tl4h6 |title=Alex y Robert Episode 1 |publisher=BBC Radio 4 |work=[[Book at Bedtime]] |date= 6 September 2010 |accessdate=6 May 2012 }}</ref> The series ran from 6–17 September 2010. ''Alex y Robert'' was launched on 12 July at the [[London Literature Festival]] to favourable reviews.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://litandspoken.southbankcentre.co.uk/2010/07/15/wena-poon-chinese-people-in-strange-places/ |title=Wena Poon Chinese people in strange places |work=Southbank Centre Literature Blog |date=15 July 2010 |first=Naomi |last=Wood |accessdate=6 May 2012 }}</ref>{{Failed verification|date=March 2014}}
In 2013, Poon released the sequel to ''Alex y Robert'' called ''Novillera''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/bidisha/wena-poon-the-fearless-gl_b_3921957.html |title=Wena Poon: The Fearless Global Author Grossing Genres, Art Forms and Publishing Platforms | Bidisha |publisher=Huffington Post |date=13 September 2013 |accessdate=15 March 2014}}</ref> The novel comments on gender, tradition and modernity and explores the ancient bull ranching culture of Spain.
In 2012–2015, Poon wrote a trilogy of Chinese-Japanese sword fighting novels<ref>{{cite web|url=http://prestige-singapore.com.sg/node/814/40%20Under%2040%202013 |title=Wena Poon |publisher=Prestige Singapore |accessdate=15 March 2014}}</ref> as a humorous, modern response to classical Ming plays, [[Kunqu|Kun opera]], [[wuxia]] television shows, and samurai films. They are published as "The Adventures of Snow Fox & Sword Girl", "Voyage to the Dark Kirin", and "The Marquis of Disobedience". The trilogy is a rumination on the history of the Chinese diaspora and their idea of a mythic China. It also examines the warrior or bushido code and its meaning for modern society and for women.<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/articles/ttVlgB8Z4Rn0lZrhLSV2WT/deadlier-than-the-male-female-warriors-in-chinese-wuxia</ref>
In 2009, Poon published four novels in her New York sci fi series, ''The Biophilia Omnibus''. During Christmas 2009, [[CNN]]'s online magazine voted it the Best Book Gift of the Year in Singapore.<ref> {{cite news |url=http://www.cnngo.com/singapore/shop/singapores-best-year-gift-guide-675995 |title=Singapore's 'best of the year' gift guide |first=Juliana |last=Lau |first2=Hatta |last2=Aziz |work=[[CNN International]] |date=18 December 2009 |accessdate=6 May 2012 }}</ref> The ''[[New Straits Times]]'' compared ''Biophilia'' to the works of film director [[Terry Gilliam]] in its book review.{{citation needed|date=March 2014}}The series has been exhibited at the [[Alternative Press Expo]] in San Francisco.
==Poetry== Poon's poetry has been published in anthologies, magazines and newspapers in Asia<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asiancha.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=544&Itemid=230 |title=Copernicus for a Singaporean Grandmother |publisher=Cha: An Asian Literary Journal |accessdate=15 March 2014}}</ref> and Australia. In 2010, she was shortlisted for the Bridport Poetry Prize in the UK<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bridportprize.org.uk/content/2010-shortlists |title=2010 shortlists |publisher=The Bridport Prize |accessdate=15 March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Campbell |first=Jen |url=http://jen-campbell.blogspot.com/2011/03/author-visit-wena-poon.html |title=this is not the six-word novel: Author Visit: Wena Poon |publisher=Jen Campbell |date=14 March 2011 |accessdate=15 March 2014}}</ref>{{Unreliable source?|date=March 2014}}.
==Education and writing fellowships== Poon graduated [[magna cum laude]] and [[Phi Beta Kappa]] from [[Harvard University]] with an honours degree in [[English Literature]].{{citation needed|date=March 2014}} She received a [[Juris Doctor]] degree from [[Harvard Law School]] and continues to practice law. In Singapore, she attended Nanyang Girls Primary, Raffles Girls Primary, [[Raffles Girls' School (Secondary)|Raffles Girls School]] and Raffles Junior College, where she was a Humanities Scholar. She was in the Gifted Education Program in Singapore. She is a fellow of the [[Hawthornden Castle]] writing fellowship in Scotland, and a visiting fellow of the International Writing Workshop of [[Hong Kong Baptist University]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://iww.hkbu.edu.hk/index.php?fl=writers_vw_2009 |title=International Writers Workshop |publisher=Hong Kong Baptist University |accessdate=15 March 2014}}</ref> In 2011, she was awarded a writer's residency by French literary press Avocats du Diable in the bullfighting region of southern France.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.m-e-l.fr/fiche-residence.php?id=4 |title=Bienvenue à la Maison des écrivains et de la littérature |language=French |accessdate=15 March 2014}}</ref>
